content:
Posted: June 17, 2016
												Amnesia: The Dark Descent is the pinacle of horror games for beginners. Always best when played with headphones on and up at a loudish volume, but not loud enough for your ears to bleed, leave that to public concert karaoke festivals.In Amnesia, you play as a young British man named Daniel who, well, has amnesia. He goes around finding notes and clues based on his previous thoughts, but as he collects all these things, he is simultaneousely being chased by an evil ghoulish spirit named The Manpig. This becomes more revealing of his name in the sequel, Machine For Pigs.Many young youtubers have gained exponential fame when playing this game on their let's play channels. These youtubers consist of popular names, such as Markiplier and PewDiePie.I love the setting of the game and the grim tone of it. Also the physics and ragdoll effects work amazingly. This game is a work of art in my opinion and I recommend it for anyone in the mood for a good scare or wanting to reach popularity on YouTube.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												9/10Highlights: Experience, Atmosphere, Sound, and SoundtrackThe benchmark of virtual terror... This game is unlike most other survival-horror games out there. Instead of running through creepy environments with pistols and melee weapons, you're stuck with nothing but a lantern in Amnesia: the Dark Descent. This game forces you to be defenseless against the many horrific creatures within the Castle Brennenburg and because of this, you must utilize stealth-like strategies in order to bypass the monsters. On paper, the gameplay is bare-boned and easy, but what really hits the player hard is the looming fear of the unknown. Unless you've watched youtube videos or seen someone else play this game, you are going in unprepared for an environment that is unfamiliar. You are more likely to fear that which you do not see rather than what is evident.- The story is somewhat clever, however your only connection to the story is through multiple notes you find throughout the levels and several scripted flashbacks.- The game's strongest point is its emphasis on a consistently claustrophobic and dark atmosphere. This is also strengthened by the quality of sounds used within this game as they are top-notch and  fit perfectly within the stone-walled and echoey castle. Along with this, the soundtrack is absolutely fear-inducing and befitting for the environment presented.- The game's weakest point is some of the puzzle mechanics. Most of the puzzles do not require much thought to figure out, however, some can take longer than others and have a tendency to frustrate the player and draw them out of game's intended experience/atmosphere. There have been moments where I'd spend large amounts of time backtracking to find something that I may have missed.I purchased this game a long while back around when it first came out and have played through it multiple times along with player-made mods (some of which are even scarier) both solo and with groups. What I have found this game to be is the bar at which other survival horrors must meet in order to emphasize true quality in the genre. This is one game that I can always bring up in a conversation about video games since it really blurs the line between fantasy and reality.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2013
												If you want scary, play this. What is scarier than running around and fighting the hordes of hell or zomies, with a big gun? I'll tell you. Running around with no weapons and no way to fight back in a decrepit castle with monsters chasing you as you unravel a past so horrible your character drank a drink to forget it all. THAT is scary. Ok now seriously, this is a thrilling game. The atmosphere of the castle is awesome, getting darker and creepier the further you go. I'm not going to ruin the story, but lets just say you never see the twist coming. This game is literally a dark descent as you go from the main floor of a castle and travel deeper and lower into a nightmarish experience. Another dynamic is that you have to stay sane while making your poor character go through all this. From the makers of the Penumbra series (don't worry I'll review that soon, good game) this is a HUGE leap forward in terms of story and scares. As the people behind WatchMojo on Youtube say, "Adult diapers are pretty much mandatory."

content:
Posted: July 4, 2011
												"I don't know what's in there, but it's weird and♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off whatever it is!" -John Carpenter's The Thing.Amnesia is a delightfully disturbing little horror story that takes place back in the 18th century. You awaken trapped inside a deserted castle, with no way out and no weapons, you can only run from one dark room to the next, trying to avoid the monstrosities that lurk the halls. Your only hope is to unearth this place's disturbing history if you want to survive the paranormal force that is chasing you, fighting to maintain your sanity as the darkness closes in. Amazingly atmospheric and excellently paced, Amnesia is a game that'll give you nightmares, and I love it!

												Amnesia: The Dark Descent, such a great and terrifying adventure! I would tilt my head around a corner and see a zombie-like beast creeping towards me! Then i'd run for a safe place. "There, a closet!" The darkness would drain my sanity and I'd start seeing things! Amnesia is a great horror game to play at night and during the day because of it's intense gameplay It'll keep you glued to your seat. You may get stuck at some parts, but hey, YouTube. If not, then good for you! Regardless, Amnesia is the best horror game I have ever played and I deffinately recommend it to those in need of a game of such epicosity!

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												This game is a modern horror classic. In addition to this, however, it is a very good adventure game. These two genres are blended together very well. Frictional Games has truly inspired game design. Many puzzles are clever and satisfying. This is one of the scariest games ever; sound and visual effects are implemented masterfully and instill undeniable dread in the player. That there is no combat further reinforces the player's vulnerability and encourages you to play intelligently to survive. Play it with friends for a fun time. If you like this game, check out Frictional's earlier games, the Penumbra series, which are games in much the same horror-adventure style.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 12, 2016
												What can I say about Amnesia, that hasn't already been said?The game is just astounding. So beautiful and well crafted with this organic, ever changing feel to them game that, no matter how much you play, allows you to discover more and continue to get chills and scares for hours upon hours. There's never been a single player game I enjoyed as much as I have enjoyed Amnesia. The story is well done, the scares are placed and done thoughtfully, and the enviroment is so vast, even when the game takes place inside a single castle. I love the heart that was put into the game, the voice acting is wonderful and the creatures are frightening. Even now, with 52 hours on record, I can still jump into the game and get chills and thrills from it. And that was without including the in depth Custom Stories, where fans or developers can create their own wonderful horror story with the provided assets of Amnesia. So much creativity and scares, and even humor, has come from the community stories to where there is no end to the game. You can keep playing Amnesia, and experience a unique and creative take on the world a hundred times over. I love this game. It has a place in my heart as one of my favorite games of all time, and I will never stop reccommending this game.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												Don't let Amnesia's reputation fool you, this isn't just another jump-scary survival horror game! It has some of that, but the real scares are pretty varied and unpredictable, and the bulk of the game is actually progressed with puzzles. Overall I'd rate it a solid 4.5/5. There are a couple of puzzles that are pretty unintuitive, while others can feel a bit *too* easy, and the occasional encounters you're supposed to avoid being noticed by are more irritating than scary, but there's still a *lot* to recommend this game over others. The graphics are lovely, the audio and controls are immersive, a lot of the concepts and monsters are honestly unsettling, and the story is well-presented and enjoyable. Plus, even though there's basically no inherent replayability, the game is longer than you'd expect!Quick Pro: Dark, immersive atmosphere.Quick Con: Stealth gameplay segments are unsatisfying.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2014
												At first i was kind of worried. Im so use to games jump scaring me into oblivion, which i feel is pretty cheap and annoying. Amnesia is better than that and clearly showes it through the entire game. The atmoshphere is superb and the storytelling is very well done. I was overall suprised to how well done the game was from a company i never really heard about, but i hope to see many more titles in the future. The unique use of physics really put you in the characters shoes where it takes time to think while trying to figure out puzzels and how to progress through the story. Along with being chased down by the monster, which can just be around the corner at any time, it truly keeps your sense survival at a high throughout the game. Personally, this is one of the best horror games i've played in years.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												So, a lot of people call this game "the scariest game they've ever played", and go on and on about the scariness, but I am evidence that it is totally possible to play this game without really being scared! Most of the "horror" of this game is just gross things (read: fleshy things) in dark rooms, which isn't really horrifying, it's just... gross stuff in dark rooms, and if that's not something that bothers you, then you'll be just fine in this game. Honestly, Daniel (the main character) is much, much more freaked out than I am! If you play this with the idea that it's a video game, and play it the same way you'd play any other video game, then it's more fun than scary! It has a cool back story and very interesting puzzles, and interesting mechanics involving keeping Daniel's mental health from deteriorating by keeping him out of the dark (which he seems to be very afraid of), and from observing disturbing events. So this is not a game where you can just run from point a to point b, you really have to think and strategize about your movements and where you go/stand to keep Daniel in a functional state. It's pretty cool and I've not played anything quite like it before! Also, rather than fighting monsters, you have to make them go away, which is also quite interesting (though there were no monsters for the entire first hour of the game and that was a bit disappointing to me), by hiding in the dark, no less! And either action, getting too close to a monster, or hanging out in the dark, will lower Daniel's sanity, so it requires some careful planning and knowing when it will be okay to come out. As briefly mentioned earlier, the story is presented in a very cool way, Daniel gave himself amnesia at the beginning and you basically have it right along with him, as you obviously don't know anything that he used to know. And as the story unfolds its like unravelling a mystery. Very cool! I also found the game a bit educational, as it takes place in the 1800's and is faithful to the time period, so I was able to look up some of the objects that are in the game and learn about what they were. All in all, this was a very enjoyable experience for me, so I give it a full recommendation! I didn't find it as scary as most people seem to, but I enjoy the gameplay and find it to be a very unique experience. I've had a lot of fun!

There are like 3 different endings and lots of puzzles to solve and itens to get. So you might want to go read a walkthrough first.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2015
												I played this game way back in 2011 or 2010 with 2 of my friends on skype. I know, the real balls play solo. But we really wanted to play it together.  I've finished it about 4 times in total with different friends (they needed to hold my hand  ;) ) but I swear to god, it was still damn scary.I have played quite a few horror games, and I must say Amnesia is one of the best atmospheric psycholocial horror i've ever played. Frictional Games are absolutely masters at it!It's not just jumpscares: it's the environment, the scenery, the distant screams and mumbling. The cracking and footsteps upstairs you hear continuesly around you. There are only slight hints that the enemy is nearby, it doesn't really tell you where to go or where it would come from. All you know what's going on is that you're in a dark room and you just wanna ♥♥♥♥ing light some candles because holy♥♥♥♥♥♥it's so dark here. :') but then you would signal a monster. Welp.I absolutely recommend this game to the horror fanatics and who love something psychological to it rather than just raw scary stuff and weird slimey stuff on the walls that's  all really forced. I swear, this game really does something to you. 5/5

content:
Posted: May 1, 2011
												Frictional Games is known as a small indie developer that has had previous success in its survival-horror Penumbra franchise. Their most recent release, Amnesia: The Dark Descent, should rightfully remove that trilogy from the throne and replace it with Amnesia. The Dark Descent is an absolutely fanstastic addition to FG's catalogue given its immersive atmosphere into a truly terrifying setting. The sound, graphics and cryptic story are first rate easily leaving behind any A-list horror titles in the dust. If you enjoy an engrossing atmosphere with excellent gameplay and don't mind having to change your trousers every once in awhile then Amnesia is a MUST HAVE!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												A great story that references real-world history and personalities and has mind-blowing twists and turns.  All while scaring the living @#%! out of you.  Be prepared for a grueling playthrough in most cases, depending on how lucky you get with the randomized monster encounters.  Best played either with a lot of friends in a room together if you want to sleep well, or alone at night with headphones if you're a masochist that's prepared to stay up all night clutching a shotgun.  If you haven't played this game yet, you need to get with the program and do it.FAIR WARNING:  I've seen things in this game that I almost wish I never had.   Squeamish players should not, I repeat SHOULD NOT read all of the books and notes inside the torture chambers.  Human beings are horrifying creatures, and the game references actual historical torture practices and devices.  While none of the acts are shown on-screen, all of the "pre-recorded" sounds are there alongside the in-depth descriptions of what was done.  There's serious nightmare-fuel in there that's a lot more terrifying than any of the monsters.  Word to the wise.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2011
												Frictional Games is known as a small indie developer that has had previous success in its survival-horror Penumbra franchise. Their most recent release, Amnesia: The Dark Descent, should rightfully remove that trilogy from the throne and replace it with Amnesia. The Dark Descent is an absolutely fanstastic addition to FG's catalogue given its immersive atmosphere into a truly terrifying setting. The sound, graphics and cryptic story are first rate easily leaving behind any A-list horror titles in the dust. If you enjoy an engrossing atmosphere with excellent gameplay and don't mind having to change your trousers every once in awhile then Amnesia is a MUST HAVE!

content:
Posted: March 22, 2014
												Graphics - Very good lighting, great textures, everything look creepy and very dark.Sound - absolutly unreal the game told me to use headphones but I have very nice surround sound speakers and let me tell you the sound from my speakers scared the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of me some times. The sounds in the game give you the creeps in your skin and make ever hair on your body stand up.Gameplay - So basic just move around crouch and click on what you want to interact with. Works very well for the game. Also you dont fight back in the game you either run hide or die. UI - Very clean and basic.Setting - underground most of the game in creepy places like cellers, sewers, tunnels castels, etc...Story: well I played half the game and took a month break from it so I didnt follow the story to well but their is lots of notes in the game that explain what area your in and why things are happening. Very intersting story tho.Scary? - Let me say this: I cried a few times ;_;Fun? Let me say this: I hate wanting to play the game because i know i will♥♥♥♥♥♥myself but love every moment of it. 9/10 for story gameplay and true horror without adding lots of blood and guts.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 22, 2014
												An excellent piece of digital-interactive artwork that uses the 4 essesntial elements of gaming (algorithm, player activity, interface, graphics) to spectacular degrees, all in order to deliver the scares and overwhelming creepiness of an experience that makes a game a true survival horror. The claustrophobic blackness of every step you take along with your character's (Daniel's) frequent gasps and whimpers over the incessant hauntings and attacks you endure throughout the campaign build a disarming immersion into a ghastly world all the advertisements and reviews of this game have promised. Although all your struggles charging through the game are inevitibly concluded with any one of the three rather disappointing endings, the sweat and shivers the whole shebang (quite effectively) offers makes it an experience totally worth a sappy resolution to forget about underneath the terrific fog of memories you'll make with the genuinely frightening gameplay and set pieces.

												This game will forever be known as one of the heralds of horror's resurgance in video games. Actual horror, not "gun + zombies" action. (Gun + zombies can be fun and well-made, of course, but it is not horror.)Although others games have come out which learned lessons from Amnesia and improved upon the execution, this game is still worth picking up when its on sale. For those who have an interest in the history of video games, though, it's a must-buy.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
 Positive + Downright disturbing story, with notes obtainable throughout the game only further detailing gruesome details of events that have taken place+ Great voice acting all-around (most notably Sam A. Mowry as Alexander)+ The well-developed physics engine allows for some entertaining puzzles and interaction with the environment+ Some good lighting effects help to punctuate the necessity of keeping out of the dark. Negative - Some poor gameplay mechanics: most notably the sanity system, which only sets out to hinder your progress rather than immerse you into the game; and even when I liberally used the lantern throughout the game, I was never close to running out of oil nor tinderboxes- While the game does manage to retain a fearful atmosphere for the most part, in actuality there are only around 5 or so enemies that can actually harm/kill you, which makes the possibility of death inconsequential and reduces the overall ‘scariness’ of the game Verdict “Amnesia: The Dark Descent does manage to effectively replicate a scary atmosphere and tell a good story, which many gamers have recognised. However, the game would have been much better suited in another format (most notably a book), as it seems that--in its current form--it is more of an interactive story than an actual game. Nevertheless, the overwhelmingly unnerving experience alone is worth a playthrough.” 7/10 TJBs

content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												After beating A Machine for Pigs I decided to move on to this game,and I can say that this game is as good as that game,if not better :)The game centers around this man named Daniel who has a bit of a case of Amnesia(hence the title),and thwarts the plans of Alexander,one man who used to be his friend until Daniel found out about his real plansFor those that have seen a bit of gameplay/other reviews,you may know that this game has puzzles,and PLENTY of them.I honestly have to say that my first time playing I just gave up when I got to the lab puzzle because of how bad I was at the game back then(xD),but after some pointers from my friend who completed the game before,and some prior knowledge from guides I saw and videos I saw I managed to beat the puzzles :),and overall the puzzles aren't too hard,so long as you know what you're doingThe atmosphere(which is typical in a horror game like this)is plentiful and actually managed to scare me in some parts,along with the monsters*looks at the water monsters*.The music is good,not much else to say about the music.The gameplay is great overall,kinda going with the puzzle stuff I mentioned earlier.You also get this lantern that once you run low on oil with you of course need to refill it,there's certain cases where you actually don't want your lantern out otherwise a monster will spot you and chase you(and possibly kill you xD)Overall this is a great horror game that I recommend to everyone for those that are looking for a really really good indie horror game,I guess my only complaint at all(and it's a small one)being the difficulty of some of the puzzles9.5/10 from me :)

												Graphics - Very good lighting, great textures, everything look creepy and very dark.Sound - absolutly unreal the game told me to use headphones but I have very nice surround sound speakers and let me tell you the sound from my speakers scared the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of me some times. The sounds in the game give you the creeps in your skin and make ever hair on your body stand up.Gameplay - So basic just move around crouch and click on what you want to interact with. Works very well for the game. Also you dont fight back in the game you either run hide or die. UI - Very clean and basic.Setting - underground most of the game in creepy places like cellers, sewers, tunnels castels, etc...Story: well I played half the game and took a month break from it so I didnt follow the story to well but their is lots of notes in the game that explain what area your in and why things are happening. Very intersting story tho.Scary? - Let me say this: I cried a few times ;_;Fun? Let me say this: I hate wanting to play the game because i know i will♥♥♥♥♥♥myself but love every moment of it. 9/10 for story gameplay and true horror without adding lots of blood and guts.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 22, 2014
												An excellent piece of digital-interactive artwork that uses the 4 essesntial elements of gaming (algorithm, player activity, interface, graphics) to spectacular degrees, all in order to deliver the scares and overwhelming creepiness of an experience that makes a game a true survival horror. The claustrophobic blackness of every step you take along with your character's (Daniel's) frequent gasps and whimpers over the incessant hauntings and attacks you endure throughout the campaign build a disarming immersion into a ghastly world all the advertisements and reviews of this game have promised. Although all your struggles charging through the game are inevitibly concluded with any one of the three rather disappointing endings, the sweat and shivers the whole shebang (quite effectively) offers makes it an experience totally worth a sappy resolution to forget about underneath the terrific fog of memories you'll make with the genuinely frightening gameplay and set pieces.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												Amnesia the Dark Decent is a puzzle/ horror game made by Frictional games.  In amnsia you must avoid monsters, solve very challenging puzzles and use the environment to your advantage as you try to remember who you are and achieve your goals.Amnesia has a very good story line in that is keeps you scared and interested with it's dark and morbid theme. Through the whole game there are also many back storys viewed in notes and flash backs to explain what happened so long ago.In this game you can only run or hide while in other horror games you can fight this one you can not, you must use your brain, senses and wits to survive. The AI is very well done it will keep you on your toes, as it attempts to hunt you and it’s good at what it does. I have not seen a single glitch in the game yet with the AI.The physics are mostly perfect, you can use the objects around you to make sounds to escape danger and also for barricading or solving complex puzzles.The soundtrack suits the environment and atmoshphere well, it brings out the best in the horrer experience and it really helps to immerse ones self into the game. This can also be usefull as it can signal the approch of an enamy or other things. The sound design is all so fairly accurate to, if you use your ears you can hear where the monsters are and the genral direction to. This also works well with the throwing of objects and contraptions as they sound unique and of good quality.What also makes this good is that it does not rely heavily on jump scares, rather it messes with your mind instead. It makes you imagine there’s an enemy round the corner, behined you or in a room close by. This means that the game uses your own imagination to scare you, as it plays mind games to make you jumpy. Graphics wise it has a unique medevil style to it well detailed with plenty of varied and well thought out locations and enviroments, each haveing it's own theme and style to it as well.One of my grudges is that there is not much variety in monsters, this can mean that monsters can get less scary or get more easy to predict as time goes on, since there is only 3-4. However the monsters that are present work and act very diffrently from each other, haveing unique sounds mechanics and aesthetics to each of them.The puzzles are varied and complex from the basics to finding a hidden item, up to working out how to fix advanced machinery and other things. This also ties in with the ability to maniplulate objects, as mentiond befor you will need to do this to compleat some puzzles.Personally I got scared over and over again I love this game, because it gives you a real sense of fear and no way to fight back unlike other games, like dead space or resident evil where you can shoot the monster and lose the fear factor quickly. SPOLIER ALERTMy last grudge is with the endings in which there are 3 one I find to be satisfiying, the other to  feeling like copy pastes of one another with only slight varation, but this is just my opnion on it. This is just my opinion but Overall amnesia the dark decent is a great game filled with horror suspence and fright, if you love horror then I definitely recommend you play this game and it’s not too pricey ever well worth the buy. I give it an 8.5 out of 10 I would rate it higher but there is a lack of monster types and the endings give this a lower score.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2012
												Amnesia captures the essence of what it is to be terrifying.  You're not a one-man army.  You're not a space marine.  You're not even a guy with just a few hours of martial arts class.  You're just an ordinary person with no memory of who he once was trying to uncover the clues behind his past (yeah I know it sounds cliche, but this is one game that makes it work really well).  You have only one defense: run.  Run as fast as you can and hide.  If it's a scary game you want then look no further.

You have only one defense: run.  Run as fast as you can and hide.  If it's a scary game you want then look no further.

												Amnesia: The Dark Descent is a first person horror game in which the protagonist, Daniel, has to recover his lost memories to find out where he is and what he was trying to accomplish before losing his memory.PROS:+ Beautiful environment + Immersive music and ambience + Many available custom stories that can be installed rather easily most of the time+ This game has been listed as the "most scary game" a few times in the past + Good variety between puzzles and monster pursuits + Fair price/content ratio CONS:- Some puzzles can take enough time to invoke irritation - Bugs sometimesDespite the fact that this game is slightly aged, it is still a very enjoyable experience even to this day. A must for any player interested in stealth and/or horror.My rating: 8.5

content:
Posted: September 14, 2015
												Reviewing horror classics this time.The game, that changed the way, scary games were made... the father of Outlast !What makes this scary?1. The Atmosphere - The atmosphere is very tense. The game takes place in dark old castle, which appears empty (oh it is not :D). Authors made the sounds very frightening and whole game makes you feel like something is following you - you may just get very paranoid.2. The Unknown - Why am i here? Who... or what is after me? WTF WAS THAT SOUND? thats the questions that will be very slowly answered.3. Defenslessness - You just have no way to fight back, your only option is to hide. Enemies are uncommon in this game, which just makes their encounter surprising and scary and relies on your quick reaction.Worth a try, but note, that this game is focused on story. Reading long notes is big part of the game - some takes you to flashback and some will hint you the solution to some puzzles, you will find along the way. There are no weapons, you will not be killing anyone in this game. They, however, may kill you :P.8/10, you will never visit any castles ever again.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												The first thing newcomers need to understand is that this game is NOT the sequel to Blue's Clues as some would suspect. But instead buckle in with your kids for a fun-filled family shooting game in the vein of Wii Sports and Mario Kart. You play as Daniel, a man who is lost in the castle looking for his Princess, Alexander. This game is definitely taking gay rights and marriage equality to new heights by introducing young children to this matter. Unfortunately, your princess is in another castle (or sanctum) and so you have to defeat Bowsers new plucky goons, the Duckfaces, along with the Creakarms in order to find him. There are various fun puzzles you have to complete, such as redirecting water in the sewer to get a silly man to stay quiet and stop disturbing the eco-system. All in all it teaches kids fantastic modern values and is not only ahead of its time in terms of content but also in gameplay.It is the first family game since Freddi Fish to allow users to make their own custom stories. Maybe you need to teach your kids the value of honesty and kindness? Valve is way ahead of you with its custom story Justine, but you can design your own with the knowledge of scripting and programming! Forget robots, Amnesia is the future.I was personally disappointed with the lack of female characters but understandably, Ubisoft is to blame.11/10 game, definitely start with your kids young.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
												Amnesia is absolutely nerve racking and terrifying. I will honetly tell you that I am not scared easily, but there were moments of the game that I just had to pause to collect my thoughts. The great thing about it was that it was not these so called "Jump-Scares" that made the game scary, and not even the monsters  themselves, but the mind going off-the-walls about what might be behind the next corner. Another frightening aspect was the intence survival, the worry of the lamp going out, the worry of being spotted by the monsterous creature only feet from you, and the fear of losing your mind. The game supplies such an intense array of terror that trying to think about the tasks you are aled with can be a challenge at times, and the simple completion of a seemingly simple puzzle or task can give you an absolute sense of accpoplishmet and self respect. I sat for several minutes telling myself how ingenius I was that I figured out one of the puzzles when I first played it. Steam may say I've only played it for a short time, but I was offline for most of it so it dosn't include my offline time. I was on it for more than 10 hours. I recomend this game to anyone and everyone because I think that this game isn't for a certain type of person, because every person will be rocked and terrifyed equally.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2015
												Why am I writing this up? It's Amnesia. It's the game that everyone points to first when someone asks "What's a scary game?" People that have never played it recommend it to people who will buy it and never play it. What am I even doing here?The truth is, I needed a reason to revisit this one. I'm a terribly jumpy person and genuinely scary games can wear me out good. The first time I played Amnesia, I never even made it to a monster. I knew I needed to give it another go and this was the perfect time to do it. And while I was playing, a thought occurred to me. Amnesia's been around for years at this point. How does it hold up in a post-Alien: Isolation world?Amnesia casts you, unsurprisingly, as an amnesiac in a drafty old castle back in the 1800s. You soon find a missive from yourself, assuring you that you didn't want those memories anyway and there's someone in the castle you really ought to kill. As you begin exploring the darkened, crumbling halls, you find that there are other residents of the castle that are none too pleased to see you. There's no fighting in this one, it's pure stealth or fleeing. The cornerstone of Amnesia's gameplay, much like Penumbra before it, is sanity. Looking at monsters, seeing freaky things happening, and being in the dark make you lose sanity. Of course, if you stand there in front of a torch, the things that want to turn your insides into outsides will have an easy time spotting you. Encounters with monsters are all about balancing your stealthy skulking against your dwindling sanity, which is only restored by progressing through the game. It's a finite resource system like food in Lone Survivor, and works to layer urgency on top of your horror. I must admit it's a bit of a bother here though, because it puts some irritating visual effects on you when it gets terribly low.The sanity effects are about the only misstep in the aesthetics, though. The graphics still hold up and manage to be rich and varied while still maintaining the dark, oppressive atmosphere. The level design is simple but effective, sending you through lavish halls and crumbling cellars and stranger places still, pacing out the frights and creatures. The big standout here though is the sound design. There is a lot more going on here than in most games, with your character making all sorts of breathing sounds and whimpers, footsteps for everyone being accurate to the surface that produces them, and even light sources making their own realistic ambient sounds. The castle itself is full of creepy sounds as well, most being apropos of nothing, but that just makes it all the more effective when it DOES signal something.I was very pleased with the pacing of the game, and found it had little to no contrivances to get you where it wanted you to be. Enemy encounters are infrequent enough to keep you on edge when they're not around, and absolutely terrify you when they are. Dealing with them is obviously less involved than in Alien: Isolation but much more free-form than, say, Outlast. I could see some of the terror being lost if you have to repeat certain sections a few times, but the game is balanced well enough with pacing and items that it shouldn't be a concern unless you're really trying to pull back the curtain for yourself.To my surprise, I found myself getting scared more often with this than in Alien. For me, Alien is much more about constant tension and the battle of wits with the xenomorph, whereas Amnesia is more about the terror of being helpless and confused. Not many games have managed to pull off the powerless protagonist angle without it becoming grating, but Amnesia owns it. Simple sounds and sudden visual effects will chill you to the bone, not as cheap jump scares but as payoffs to the incredible atmosphere the game maintains at all times. I feel confident in saying that no matter how far the genre progresses, Amnesia will always have a place of honor among the games that truly terrify.

number of helpful: 14 of 26 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 6, 2016
												I... don't get it. This is supposed to be one of the greatest horror games of all time? Did I go into it with too high expectations? Did playing Frictional's other games first desensitize me?My problems with Amnesia can be easily explained when you look at the second sentence on it's Steam page:"A game about immersion, discovery and living through a nightmare."Immersion. I had no issues immersing myself in Penumbra's universe. SOMA, despite having a very talkative protagonist, was still a relatable character, and I had no issues seeing myself in his shoes. Amnesia, however, is based around a very gimmicky sanity mechanic. It sounds like a good idea in theory, especially considering the Lovecraftian themes the game is touching on, but in practice it only served to break immersion. How am I supposed to find this world scary, or even take it seriously when the POV character is waaaaay more scared of the wind blowing open a door than I am? Not just scared, cowering in fear. Crawling and spasming on the ground over nothing and I'm just sitting here going... what the ♥♥♥♥, dude?Discovery. SOMA had no lighting issues. Penumbra was very dark at places, but I never ran out of glowsticks or flashlight batteries. Amnesia, on the other hand? Not only is it much worse lit than Penumbra, but light sources are extremely scarce. How am I supposed to know anything about my environment, or discover anything, when I can't see a ♥♥♥♥ing thing? Not only that, but the game discourages you from spending time in the darkness. It increases your insanity. So here I am bumping between walls, trying to find my way out of a room while my character is having a panic attack because he is literally afraid of the dark?Living through a nightmare. I'll give the game that. Playing this thing was a nightmare. Not a fun nightmare either. Not even a scary one. Just an underwhelming and thoroughly boring one.No, I do not reccomend this game. Penumbra: Overture had a few problems but I loved every minute of it, Penumbra: Black Plague is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed masterpiece. Penumbra: Requiem exists. SOMA is very, very good, as I mentioned in my review of it. Amnesia... is an extremely overhyped pile of♥♥♥♥♥♥ It's got nothing on Frictional's other work.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2014
												After waiting a couple of years to actually get my hands on this game, I have to say it was well worth the wait. The whole experience is brilliant. If you're looking for a game that drags you in and doesn't let you go even after you've stopped playing then this is the game for you. From the eerie corridors at the start of the game, to the claustrophobic dungeons as you progress, the atmosphere never eases up and a constant sense of dread follows you throughout the story. The story, the immersion and the gameplay are all great and I'd definitely reccomend this to anyone looking for a good horror game and an immersive experience.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2014
												Tis is the best horror game, or maybe horror story, every fabricated! That should be enough to say, but, really i should say more.          If you are scared easily you will not see the genius that was required to make the atmosphere of Dark Descent because all you will be worried about are the "Monsters".        BUT, if you can handle the scares, you will see the true horror of Amnesia, insanity. The game isnt just about monsters since they may be real or they could be all in your head, are you really roaming a monster infested mansion?            Or is it all in your head? content:
Posted: April 10, 2014
												This is such a fantastic game - even though I'm having problems with it, no matter how many times I die to monsters (or end up getting stuck inside a room) I just want to keep playing. In fact, I'm doing a series of highlights videos on my Youtube channel where I'm playing through this pretty much completely blind. I'm not picking up any notes or journals or diaries; I'm not reading anything, and I'm still having a blast with it when I'm wandering around not knowing what to do. I guess that's just another great thing about this game; they managed to make a coherent story using only flashbacks, so that even without reading any of the important stuff I still kind of know why I'm doing what I'm doing. I'm even looking forward to finishing this first playthrough so I can go back on my own and read everything up, pick up all the details I missed and see how much that changes the story.This is the first part of my series if you want to check it out: 


YouTube™ Video: Amnesia: The Dark Descent - Let's Play Highlights - Part 1 

			Views: 34		

			Wherein I skip every note, journal, memento, and diary while playing Amnesia: The Dark Descent. If you enjoyed the video, leave a like - it really helps!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												If I were to describe this game in one word, that word would be "HolyCrapThisGameIsScary!".Amnesia: The Dark Descent does not rely simply on jump scares, though there are plenty of them, instead it reels you in through it's immersive story, creepy environment, and its ability to mess with the senses. Venturing through the eerie dungeons gives you a sense of wonder and the urge to continue along the course. The game is scary but the storyline keeps pulling you back in, not allowing you to stop playing for more than a few hours.Amnesia: The Dark Descent is special because of the fact that it does not give you great power. You can simply run and hide from any kind of creature that you encounter. You cannot fight back when being attacked, you merely die, and must come up with a way to outsmart your "opponent".  This game also affects "Daniel" the Character you are playing as. After the game carries on he begins to become insane, making it harder to perform simple tasks and in the process striking fear in your soul!I will say that this game is not like any others before it; in fact it will inspire the Horror Survival Genre forever. This is nearly the pinnacle of Horror games because it gives the gamer a sense of curiosity and does not allow itself to be forgotten very easily in your mind.I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys the adrenaline rush of being scared and to anyone who loves a great mysterious story.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												Amnesia has a special something that most games fail to acheive. That is what you become aware of almost as soon as you finish the game. The only way I could possibly describe the game once I finished was... Wow... Just wow... The game is probobly the example of what a horror game should be for all the indie creators and AAA developers out there. However, what does this game achieve in?To start off, we must discuss the story. The story is what makes up a game for me as a gamer. Game has bad story, its a bad game. There has only been a handful of games that go against this, but even still, those handful don't match the rest. However, Amnesia's story is phenomenal and a lot darker then you anticipate. When I entered, I thought this game was going to have a very gothic story (which it did) but did not see the grisly scenes of torture coming up on the plot. Even if this is all told in flashbacks and distrubing hallucinations, it does not take away from the fact the story is messed up. YOU WILL REGRET TRYING TO REMEMBER WHAT YOU FORGOT. Daniel says to himself in the very beginning "I choose to forget" and you'll see why sure enough. To put it simply, do not doubt for a moment this game's story will get to you.Onto Gameplay, it's a straight through adventure with puzzles and terror thrown in the mix. The game is actually pretty open believe it or not, not Minecraft kind of open but a open where some of the rooms have little purpose but to be there. (Which is what I believe Amnesia: Machine for Pigs I lacking, but that's not the point). The castle is a fun place to explore and the puzzles why can have little things you might miss, truly are not frustrating. If you want a frustrating horror puzzle game, go to Anna:Extended Edition. While that was not a bad game at all, the puzzles get very annoying. Amnesia however masters the right balance of puzzles and terror and really make a good game out of it. Part of the gameplay as well, is as you might expect hiding, running, and screaming. I did not die much during the game, which is a good thing, but the moments I ran and hid sent chills rushing through my spine and got the adreniline pumping. However, I'll discuss that in scarinessThe game is scary, every moment is scary, this game is the scariest game out there. You will not know what to expect, and some of the areas will truly scare you. I got scared several times and panicked at little and big things, the game's atmopshere really prepares you for this game. If you don't believe me, do the "immersion" the game discusses at the beginning and do just that. You will surely have a heart attack... (I suggest calling 911 before playing the game, so in the eight minutes that it takes for them to arrive, you'll have to wait little)The last thing I need to discuss is the Audio and Graphics. The graphics look great, I have to say, maybe not what everyone else seems to find "great" these days but they are good. There were only two moments where I got a buggy graphic or thought "They could have made this better" but truly its good. The game was also made in 2010 when we still were just starting to improve graphics, so I have no complaints. The Audio however is what is really important to discuss, the Audio is what makes the game scary. The whole game I played with headphones, though it made me cower in fear and suffer serious mental issues, I don't regret a thing. There is a certain thing that the game does with it's audio, that just makes it so good. You don't even need a screen for some of the audio to send shivers down your spine. It sticks with you far after the game is done and when you hear that Grunt or Brute's cry of anger you will fear for your life.Overall, the game is excellent. Do not miss out on this game. It is one of the best game I have ever played in my life and sure as heck the best horror game.Story 9/10Gameplay 9/10Scariness 10/10Graphic & Audio 9/10Overall: 9/10

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												Amnesia is easily the scariest game I've ever played, and I'm a big fan of horror games. Games like Resident Evil are a lot of fun, but barely manage to scare me. Also, what's up with Slender being like the standard for a good horror game. Slender is scary once, the first time you see Slenderman. After that you're just wandering through the woods while the same guy chases you. It's good for a free horror game, yet some people think it's the scariest game ever, but it doesn't come close to Amnesia. Anyway, Amnesia scares you in so many ways. Not only are the enemies chasing you incredibly disturbing, there are lots of kind of less obvious, but incredibly scary, moments. Once I went into a room, saw a cage with a dead body in it hanging from the ceiling, and later when I returned to the room it was gone... The story is also very creepy if you pay attention to the notes you find. If you don't use an online guide, like me, the game will take you somewhere from 8-10 hours, but if you do use a guide then it shouldn't take longer than 5 or so. I actually liked their previous games, The Penumbra series, better than Amnesia in terms of gameplay, but Amnesia is much scarier.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												Amnesia is probably one of my favourite games of all time and cetainly my favourite horror title of all time. The game itself plays very well and provides a very good atmosphere and mood. The enemies are always dangerous and always pose a threat to the player since you only have the capacity to outrun them over short distances and long distances will result in you being caught and likely killed. The games scare factor varies based on the player I myself didn't find it scary however it was tense and immersive and I enjoyed the experiece a lot.The games visuals are rather dated however, the lighting could use some touching up and some of the textures look as if they are from a very old game. However this didn't seem to ruin the immersion for me as its possible to interact with almost every object within the game world such a levers, candles, torches, barrels, crates and books to name a few, even those objects that aren't relevant are able to be interected with. This adds an extra layer of depth to the gameplay as it gets the player thinking about what is needed to complete certain sections and puzzles within the game. I was also quite impressed with the storyline and the way it was told as the notes system and being able to read into it by picking them up throughout the game allows for various interpretations of the story and also allows players to connect with it at their own pace. The average amount of play time it takes to complete the game I feel is also worth it for the price as it is a very enjoyable time and can potentially be played through again dependent on the players view of the game. This game also incorporates a few good mechanics such as the depleting lantern oil and insanity. This adds to the difficultly and fits in with it being in the survival horror genre. It could also signficantly alter the way some players move through the game.Overall: Fantastic, 90/100

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												I'm one of those gamers that get scary games despite being terrified by them. Some horror games (i.e. Five Nights at Freddy's and Resident Evil) I can play because I've learned how to handle the jumpscares and the horror aspects....That's not the case here...The atmosphere and the ambient noises are what really set the "horror" mood for this game. Hearing footsteps from above is spine-chilling and the sound of your own heart racing brings the horror to life. The sudden noises will stop you dead in your tracks. Every room is another suprise and shock waiting to appear.Multiple times I've stopped playing because I'm terrified of what's in the next room.This game can burn out your fear meter until you just stare blankly at your screen, feeling nothing but fear and emptiness.7.8/10Pros- Smooth gameplay- Good story to follow- Always has the player on edge- For the ones looking for a rush of fear and adrenalineCons- Terrifying as Hell- Too much water- Did I mention it's terrifying?- The rush of fear and adrenaline is 2much4me

Lovercraft:"Non sapevo, né mi premeva saperlo, se l’avventura che stavo vivendo fosse un sogno, magia, oppure frutto della follia. Non aveva importanza alcuna per me, che ero più che mai deciso a contemplare ad ogni costo lo splendore e la gioia. Non sapevo chi fossi, né che cosa fossi, e neppure a quale mondo appartenessi; tuttavia, mentre avanzavo solitario incespicando ad ogni passo, nacque in me la coscienza di una sorta di spaventosa memoria latente che rendeva il mio procedere non del tutto casuale." [Cit. L'estraneo di H.P. Lovercraft... che non è un motoscafo che cavalca il pelo dell'acqua ;)]

												I think Amnesia : The Dark Descent is one of the scariest games ever made.We can understand that because the game was made by an independent developer. In Amnesia, you run and hide, the only answer to the encounter between you and a monster is to escape. The fear is omnipresent, when you hear screaming voices, when you open a door, when you go into the darkness of a room without light, your heart is going crazy. This is one of the game I will remember all my life as a game of quality.The game worths more than it's original price. However, I bought it and I didn't finish a level, yet.9/10

												There isn't much to say about Amnesia: The Dark Descent that hasn't been said already. It's a very effective survival horror experience just teeming with atmosphere. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 26, 2013
												I will be the first to say that some of the scares in this game are cheap and the programing is pretty predictable at times. Even when you know that sound you heard in one room is nothing, but that corner that is silent is most likely more dangerous, you still get a bit nervous. Honestly, this is probably one of the best and scariest horror games out there. Most people love this game, and it is easy to see why. You will spend most of the gameplay solving puzzles, and half way through the game you will find yourself hiding from monsters a lot. Even so, there are a few curve balls thrown into the game to make it feel fresh. One of my favorite disturbing moments in the game was when I had to try to get away from an invisible water creature by throwing remains acrossed the room hoping that it would go after that instead of me. This game is disturbing, frightening, and chilling, with a great story to boot. Fans of the horror genre will love this game.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2010
												This was one of the most intense horror games I have ever played through.  Rarely does a game make me jump, but this managed to do it many times.  The atmosphere is chilling, to the point where you are afraid to even move to the next area, lest you come across a beast that will tear you to pieces in seconds.  The use of darkness causing your character's insanity to warp the reality you are perceiving was a great idea.  The light is your only friend here.  It is a short but thrilling ride, but I feel the price reflects that.  If you're a fan of horror/survival games, I can't recommend this one enough.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 19, 2013
												Truly a worthy successor to the Penumbra Series and vastly more scary, Dark Descent is DAMN good.ScaresThis game is scary as all hell if you follow the directions (play at night or in the darkest room available, use headphone with good volume level, allow no distractions). From start the finish you feel your own insanity meter spiraling out of control as you immerse yourself into the atmosphere.. This game will have you begging for a brightly-lit room in which to collect your sanity before pressing on.PuzzlesThere are a solid amount of puzzles that are typically never obvious (A Machine for Pigs, I'm looking at you). There are also many items to collect and use throughout the game (A Machine for Pigs, I'm looking at you again). They also act as a contrast to the scary sections of the game, allowing yourself to take a break from being insane.Plot / StoryThe story takes a back-seat to nothing and aligns with what I would expect coming from the Penumbra series. If you are interested, the game provides a wealth of back-stories and side-stories to explore.Other Stuff- Game's good- You should buy it and play it- If you like it you should go buy the Penumbra series - 3 games for cheap!

												I found out about this game through a review in PC Gamer magazine. I'll be the first to admit that I was skeptical about the mechanics (no weapons? what!?) but they are the key to the terror of this game. In any other scary game, you can just whip out a plasma cannon to destroy the things that scare you. In this game, all you can do is cower in fear and hide. This key mechanic, whereby you are rewarded for hiding raises the fear levels unlike anything I have ever played. When you round a corner in some dank, dark castle sub-floor and hear an inhuman growl, I guarantee you will soil your pants. The game itself oozes atmosphere, and it even encourages you to play in the dark with headphones on. This game is absolute ART that will TERRIFY you. I tell people all the time, "Amnesia makes Dead Space feel like a walk through a sunny, butterfly-filled meadow." There were literally moments where I had to step away from it to gather myself, it is THAT SCARY. Do yourself a favor and GET THIS GAME!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2015
												Rejuvenating survival horror. Perfect, endlessly unsettling sound design. Horrifying environments. Pure chilling Lovecraftian narrative told and unearthed in a consistently engaging manner. Puzzles that are simple enough to not become frustrating and challenging enough to not feel like pointless busywork. An unshakeable feeling of being chased and even in the dingiest corners being constantly out in the open and exposed to danger. Hiding from monsters that more often than not aren't there, abusing every inch of your imagination, and when they are there delivering terrifying sequences of frantic escape slamming doors behind you and terrified hiding cowering into walls desperately trying not to be seen, having to balance attempts at avoiding them with your dwindling sanity in the dark. Leaping from box to box in a flooded room avoiding the invisible creature that waits in the water, and the panicked rush to safety when you inevitably slip and hear the splashing rapidly approaching behind you. Lighting, sanity and "flight not fight" mechanics that have impacted so much in the five years since its release, making it hard to imagine the horror landscape of the 2010s without it. The defining horror game of the decade so far.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2011
												What can be said about Amnesia that hasn't already been said? Rather than attempt to quantify what makes Amnesia one of the most popular horror games to date, I'll just say that if you're looking for scares that are actually scary, look no further.Amnesia is a horror game with inventory puzzles and an odd little sanity mechanic I like to call "hide and go soil yourself". While my experience with other horror games has been limited, I can say without a doubt that Amnesia may provide one of the most visceral experiences you have ever gone through in a video game.Amnesia is an absolute joy to play with your friends. If you can manage the time, play through it once on your own, then invite your friends to play it and watch them experience it for the first time. Amnesia is the only game that I have found able to inspire such a feeling of well-meaning spite towards your friends. The kind of spite where you want them to go through the same horrors you did just to see who has better bladder control.When you're done with Amnesia, and you've plumbed the depths of any of the interesting custom levels made by the community, the previous, though unrelated story-wise, Penumbra series by the same developers can wring out a few more decent scares. Just make sure your heart can take it before purchasing.

content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
												I would recommend this game for those who like horror games, but can't fight. As in you have to use your intelligence and quick thinking to beat the game. Mainly from running away from the enemies in the game. The game is weird, yet I enjoyed it. I don't have any issues with this game or any disappointments either.Story: The game is about a guy named Daniel, who has suffered from Amnesia and doesn't remember who he is or where he is. As you explore the mansion or castle, you discover weird secrets(notes) left behind by yourself. You encounter weird enemies and things throughout the game as you try to find your way out(I believe).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												4 years later, and this is still the scariest game I've ever played. If you truely enjoy scaring the crap out of yourself, and cry in fear and laughter. This is truely the game for you. I would also recommend playing at night in the dark for fuller effect. Also makes a better experience if you have friends/family in the room so they can laugh at you, (Or turn the tables and make them play the game and laugh at their missery.) Or be brave and play it by yourself, however I'd recommend having a webcam and screen capture to record your reactions, as you reflect and laugh at yourself if playing solo.The grunts and brutes are terrifying, the sound effects and especially the music help build an 'unsetteling' effect on you. And the mechanics to open doors and draws are down right perfect. The Insane effect is very unforgiving which will require you to stay in lit areas, leaving the chance for a grunt to approach you.After the game is finished I'd highly recommend playing the Justine add-on and the many custom stories created by the community. Many of them will have you re-living the Amnesia experience.Amnesia the Dark Decent gets a 10/10 in my vote. And is, hands down, the most horrifying experience I've ever lived.

content:
Posted: February 11, 2012
												Amnesia ist ein ganz besonderes Spiel. Bei Amnesia erkundet man aus der Ego-Sicht eine Welt im Traum des Protagonisten, eine riesige Burg mit vielen dunklen und gruseligen Geheimnissen. Das Spielprinzip basiert darauf, dass man unter Druck zum Überleben animiert wird, flüchtet, sich versteckt und versucht den schrecklichen Gestalten zu entgehen, die die verlassen Mauern und Gänge der Burg unsicher machen. Man hat einfach Angst! Dabei findet man keinerlei Waffen oder Gegenstände, mit welchen man sich wehren könnte. Ein völlig neues Spielgefühl entsteht, wenn man panisch vor einem Monster wegläuft, Türen hintersich verschließt, durch welche man ebenfalls verfolgt wird, nur um weiter im Stress das Weite zu suchen und dem Geheimnis dieser Traumwelt auf die Spur zu kommen. Ich hatte selten solche Angst in einem Spiel, wie in Amnesia! TOP!

content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												There aren't many horror games that and truly make you feel hesitant to play them not because they're bad games but because they truly keep you on edge. Amnesia: The Dark Descent is one of those games, and yes, I admit that I completely broke down at one point for fear that a monster would show up and slice up my back.Unfortunately, if you think about it for a while, the monsters become quite predictable and easy to avoid. When this happens, the horror element is lost, but it won't be until about 3/5 through the game before this happens. Still, the game itself and the occasional wonderful custom stories for it make it a worthy purchase.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16, 2011
												Why is Amnesia so fantastic? It breaches the mindless, scripted scares that encompass other modern horror games today through a unique approach. This game throws you into a dark world where you remember nothing about where you are or why you are there, except that there is an unknown shadow chasing you as you try to decipher your purpose. Sitting in the dark causes you to hallucinate and slowly lose your mind, and you can die simply from looking at a monster for too long. The fear of the unknown, immersive ambience, and tense motifs are what scare the hell out of anyone attempting to play this game.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2010
												This was one of the most intense horror games I have ever played through.  Rarely does a game make me jump, but this managed to do it many times.  The atmosphere is chilling, to the point where you are afraid to even move to the next area, lest you come across a beast that will tear you to pieces in seconds.  The use of darkness causing your character's insanity to warp the reality you are perceiving was a great idea.  The light is your only friend here.  It is a short but thrilling ride, but I feel the price reflects that.  If you're a fan of horror/survival games, I can't recommend this one enough.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 19, 2015
												Disturbing, engrossing, and challenging, The Dark Descent is both a harrowing horror experience and a decently well realized narrative with careful attention paid to nailing the pacing subtleties.Gameplay is simple and has quality stealth mechanics and sound cues. The adventure game-y puzzles and a plethora of crafting tasks can get a little tiresome by the final strech, but I never lost the investment to beat the game. The experience begins itself perfectly, calling the player to persevere and conquer the ever consuming darkness and NOT be afraid (although you will be).Play it with the lights off and headphones. It's a great ride.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2015
												Rejuvenating survival horror. Perfect, endlessly unsettling sound design. Horrifying environments. Pure chilling Lovecraftian narrative told and unearthed in a consistently engaging manner. Puzzles that are simple enough to not become frustrating and challenging enough to not feel like pointless busywork. An unshakeable feeling of being chased and even in the dingiest corners being constantly out in the open and exposed to danger. Hiding from monsters that more often than not aren't there, abusing every inch of your imagination, and when they are there delivering terrifying sequences of frantic escape slamming doors behind you and terrified hiding cowering into walls desperately trying not to be seen, having to balance attempts at avoiding them with your dwindling sanity in the dark. Leaping from box to box in a flooded room avoiding the invisible creature that waits in the water, and the panicked rush to safety when you inevitably slip and hear the splashing rapidly approaching behind you. Lighting, sanity and "flight not fight" mechanics that have impacted so much in the five years since its release, making it hard to imagine the horror landscape of the 2010s without it. The defining horror game of the decade so far.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2011
												Horror fans take note! This is the scariest game to come out in quite a while. Walking down those dark corridors can be quite unnerving. Your only "weapon" is your trusty lamp that can stave off insanity, but will alert monsters to your location. Sometimes when your character goes insane, he'll halucinate bugs crawling on his face. That was a nice touch. There's also a part where you have to throw dismembered body parts into the water to distract the water monsters long enough to make a run for it. The next time I came across water I was more than a little aprehensive to walk through it. It took me 13 hours to beat. The puzzles arn't super hard. I admit I did have to cheat to find out how to get the elevator working. After running blindly through labrynth-like hallways escaping monsters, the puzzles can be a nice relief. For the full horror experience you'll definitely want to play this one alone in the dark with good head phones. It's $20 (or cheaper) and well worth the cost.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
												This game. This game is genius. There is no other way to describe it. Amnesia excels beyond any other game at making you feel completely helpless. Monsters? Yes. But weapons? A big fat NO. The only way you stay alive is by evading and hiding from monsters. And really, the scariness of Amnesia is not the monsters, but the lack thereof. It's the moments when you're walking through a completely silent hallway and your lantern oil runs out that are the scariest. I don't have any other words besides genius to describe this amazing work. Buy this game. You will be scared out of your wits at times, but when you finish the game as I did, you will realize its sheer genius.Well done, Frictional Games! A big salute goes out to you for this work of art!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 26, 2013
												I will be the first to say that some of the scares in this game are cheap and the programing is pretty predictable at times. Even when you know that sound you heard in one room is nothing, but that corner that is silent is most likely more dangerous, you still get a bit nervous. Honestly, this is probably one of the best and scariest horror games out there. Most people love this game, and it is easy to see why. You will spend most of the gameplay solving puzzles, and half way through the game you will find yourself hiding from monsters a lot. Even so, there are a few curve balls thrown into the game to make it feel fresh. One of my favorite disturbing moments in the game was when I had to try to get away from an invisible water creature by throwing remains acrossed the room hoping that it would go after that instead of me. This game is disturbing, frightening, and chilling, with a great story to boot. Fans of the horror genre will love this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2016
												Amnesia: The Dark Descent is a revivification of the atmospheric horror game. Unable to fight the abominations that stalk you, Amnesia leaves you alone in a gritty atmospheric, slowly turning horrific, setting that pushes you toward finding the answers to your ailment, Amnesia. The game focuses on a few game-play mechanics such as health, mental health (though I believe is called insanity in the game), and finding what are essentially keys for the next zone (though are often items and puzzles) while for the most part being actively stalked by monsters. Some of the most notable elements of the game-play are the mental health meter and its gripping pacing. The mental health in the game involves your ability to stay in the light and avoid gazing at monsters for too long. The second being probably the most important feature. Once the unknown becomes the known it becomes a lot less frightful, so having a game-play mechanic that punishes the unknown becoming known it incredibly smart and well done and it is sufficient enough to last almost the entire game (the later areas somewhat abandon this concept, and it becomes a lot less scary for doing so). Until the end of the game it does a good job of pacing areas of horror and peace, though unannounced to the player, and never once did I feel cheated by the monsters. Overall I would suggest Amnesia to anyone who is looking for a dark, gripping, and atmospheric horror game that will last you a couple of days (approximately 8 hours of content).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 4, 2016
												A sweet, super short and absolutely spoiler-free review and opinion on the game Amnesia: The Dark Descent by Frictional Games.Close your door, shut down the lights and let the darkness sink in... The only visible light source being the computer monitor. The most rewarding experience will only be achievable in total darkness. Amnesia: The Dark Descent will take care of the rest.As a horror game this gets a lot of things right with just only a handful of annoyances mixed in. The game is definitely recommendable to anyone who is able to handle a lot of spooks and many more jump scares.The game goes even as far as planting some philosophical and truly thought provoking concepts in players head. So after one has beaten the game the memories about the “descending” aren’t necessarily the scary bits and pieces but the moments when the thoughts about “right” and “wrong” start to have debates in players mind. That’s perhaps the most rewarding aspect of the whole packet.My IGN-score: 8.5 / 10***SPOILERS (for those who really want to have a ‘clean’ experience)***Pros:- enjoyable surroundings- atmosphere- the dance of light and darkness (to put it nicely ^_^)Cons:- low resolution textures (the game is nearly seven years old so hardly surprising)- not enough notes, diaries etc to read (completely subjective viewpoint)- less appealing in the end (ok, this one is kinda a stretch {as I said there isn't much to criticise})

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2012
												One of the scariest, if not the scariest horror game on the market. Amnesia is similar to Penumbra in terms of puzzles, clever problem solving and a setting of helplessness in the face of your enemies. Caught within a Prussian medieval castle in the 1800's, you are immediately caught in the middle of the story, but due to amnesia (title drop) you have no recollection of past events, with nothing but a note to yourself and a feeling of being hunted on your mind. Amnesia: The Dark Descent, like Penumbra integrates very interactive physics that not only aid in the adrenaline rush of being chased by a gatherer with a slow-closing door but also said physics are key for the many puzzles of Brennenburg. After playing Penumbra though it's hard to deny that they're both the same type of game but in vastly different settings. In terms of horror, though, Amnesia takes the (blood-soaked) cake.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												If I were to describe this game in one word, that word would be "HolyCrapThisGameIsScary!".Amnesia: The Dark Descent does not rely simply on jump scares, though there are plenty of them, instead it reels you in through it's immersive story, creepy environment, and its ability to mess with the senses. Venturing through the eerie dungeons gives you a sense of wonder and the urge to continue along the course. The game is scary but the storyline keeps pulling you back in, not allowing you to stop playing for more than a few hours.Amnesia: The Dark Descent is special because of the fact that it does not give you great power. You can simply run and hide from any kind of creature that you encounter. You cannot fight back when being attacked, you merely die, and must come up with a way to outsmart your "opponent".  This game also affects "Daniel" the Character you are playing as. After the game carries on he begins to become insane, making it harder to perform simple tasks and in the process striking fear in your soul!I will say that this game is not like any others before it; in fact it will inspire the Horror Survival Genre forever. This is nearly the pinnacle of Horror games because it gives the gamer a sense of curiosity and does not allow itself to be forgotten very easily in your mind.I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys the adrenaline rush of being scared and to anyone who loves a great mysterious story.

content:

												A fascinating little game.  At its absolute best, it delivers an exceedingly unsettling experience; at some point, you'll almost certainly find yourself cowering in a dark corner hoping desperately that something doesn't kill you and balancing the warm comfort of a candle against the risk something will come around the corner and rip your face off.  At its worst, it's a slow puzzler with sometimes-illogical requirements.Still, as a short, play-it-in-two-solid-sittings game, it's hard to top the  feel it delivers.  Well worth the 6-8 hours it'll take to finish.
