number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2013
												This is the horror game you are looking for. Play this with headphones alone at night and you will experience a fear no other games or movies can give you. At the most intense moments, it's hard not to quit the game and leave the room in utter fear. You can't simply fight the monsters and ghosts in this game, so you will have to be careful not being spotted or not to make too much sound, or esle they'll come after you... and if they do, you need to run as fast as possible, while under the constant pressure of not going insane. If you are the kind of person looking for the scariest of games, this is the game for you. With a long, dark main story and a million DLC packs and user-created levels, the gameplay only ends when you're hiding under your bed, after smashing your PC in utter terror and fear.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												Amnesia has a special something that most games fail to acheive. That is what you become aware of almost as soon as you finish the game. The only way I could possibly describe the game once I finished was... Wow... Just wow... The game is probobly the example of what a horror game should be for all the indie creators and AAA developers out there. However, what does this game achieve in?To start off, we must discuss the story. The story is what makes up a game for me as a gamer. Game has bad story, its a bad game. There has only been a handful of games that go against this, but even still, those handful don't match the rest. However, Amnesia's story is phenomenal and a lot darker then you anticipate. When I entered, I thought this game was going to have a very gothic story (which it did) but did not see the grisly scenes of torture coming up on the plot. Even if this is all told in flashbacks and distrubing hallucinations, it does not take away from the fact the story is messed up. YOU WILL REGRET TRYING TO REMEMBER WHAT YOU FORGOT. Daniel says to himself in the very beginning "I choose to forget" and you'll see why sure enough. To put it simply, do not doubt for a moment this game's story will get to you.Onto Gameplay, it's a straight through adventure with puzzles and terror thrown in the mix. The game is actually pretty open believe it or not, not Minecraft kind of open but a open where some of the rooms have little purpose but to be there. (Which is what I believe Amnesia: Machine for Pigs I lacking, but that's not the point). The castle is a fun place to explore and the puzzles why can have little things you might miss, truly are not frustrating. If you want a frustrating horror puzzle game, go to Anna:Extended Edition. While that was not a bad game at all, the puzzles get very annoying. Amnesia however masters the right balance of puzzles and terror and really make a good game out of it. Part of the gameplay as well, is as you might expect hiding, running, and screaming. I did not die much during the game, which is a good thing, but the moments I ran and hid sent chills rushing through my spine and got the adreniline pumping. However, I'll discuss that in scarinessThe game is scary, every moment is scary, this game is the scariest game out there. You will not know what to expect, and some of the areas will truly scare you. I got scared several times and panicked at little and big things, the game's atmopshere really prepares you for this game. If you don't believe me, do the "immersion" the game discusses at the beginning and do just that. You will surely have a heart attack... (I suggest calling 911 before playing the game, so in the eight minutes that it takes for them to arrive, you'll have to wait little)The last thing I need to discuss is the Audio and Graphics. The graphics look great, I have to say, maybe not what everyone else seems to find "great" these days but they are good. There were only two moments where I got a buggy graphic or thought "They could have made this better" but truly its good. The game was also made in 2010 when we still were just starting to improve graphics, so I have no complaints. The Audio however is what is really important to discuss, the Audio is what makes the game scary. The whole game I played with headphones, though it made me cower in fear and suffer serious mental issues, I don't regret a thing. There is a certain thing that the game does with it's audio, that just makes it so good. You don't even need a screen for some of the audio to send shivers down your spine. It sticks with you far after the game is done and when you hear that Grunt or Brute's cry of anger you will fear for your life.Overall, the game is excellent. Do not miss out on this game. It is one of the best game I have ever played in my life and sure as heck the best horror game.Story 9/10Gameplay 9/10Scariness 10/10Graphic & Audio 9/10Overall: 9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2011
												What can be said about Amnesia that hasn't already been said? Rather than attempt to quantify what makes Amnesia one of the most popular horror games to date, I'll just say that if you're looking for scares that are actually scary, look no further.Amnesia is a horror game with inventory puzzles and an odd little sanity mechanic I like to call "hide and go soil yourself". While my experience with other horror games has been limited, I can say without a doubt that Amnesia may provide one of the most visceral experiences you have ever gone through in a video game.Amnesia is an absolute joy to play with your friends. If you can manage the time, play through it once on your own, then invite your friends to play it and watch them experience it for the first time. Amnesia is the only game that I have found able to inspire such a feeling of well-meaning spite towards your friends. The kind of spite where you want them to go through the same horrors you did just to see who has better bladder control.When you're done with Amnesia, and you've plumbed the depths of any of the interesting custom levels made by the community, the previous, though unrelated story-wise, Penumbra series by the same developers can wring out a few more decent scares. Just make sure your heart can take it before purchasing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2012
												One of the scariest, if not the scariest horror game on the market. Amnesia is similar to Penumbra in terms of puzzles, clever problem solving and a setting of helplessness in the face of your enemies. Caught within a Prussian medieval castle in the 1800's, you are immediately caught in the middle of the story, but due to amnesia (title drop) you have no recollection of past events, with nothing but a note to yourself and a feeling of being hunted on your mind. Amnesia: The Dark Descent, like Penumbra integrates very interactive physics that not only aid in the adrenaline rush of being chased by a gatherer with a slow-closing door but also said physics are key for the many puzzles of Brennenburg. After playing Penumbra though it's hard to deny that they're both the same type of game but in vastly different settings. In terms of horror, though, Amnesia takes the (blood-soaked) cake.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												Pros:-Can use surrounding objects to your advantage-Very Scary-Difficult, Challenging-Amazing Soundtrack-Interesting gameplay mechanics (Sanity Meter, can't stay in the dark long enough)-Levels are non - linear, which makes it feel more ordinary (Buildings aren't built in a linear fashion, a corridor would have mutliple rooms on the sides, etc).-Amazing atmosphereCons:-Monsters don't wander around for a long time, they spawn when the player walks in a certain area. There isn't a set number of Monsters that roam / patrol the area, which would make it so that you would have to spend a certain amount of time in an area.-Can't pick up candles / monsters are somewhat immune to objects (I can't hit a shovel very hard to stun a brute).-Game is somewhat short (They should have added some more levels / more rooms to explore).In other words, 8 / 10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2012
												I rate this game #1 constipation reliever. The whole dark atmosphere and the fact that there is always something lurking around the corner is very paranoia inducing. There is also the fact that there is absolutely NO way to defend yourself; running away and hiding is the only key to survival. Keeping your sanity, as well as your health, is a big factor in gameplay. Your character suffers from nyctophobia (the fear of darkness) which, as a result, causes your character to go insane when staying in the darkness for a prolonged amount of time. This sets a new difficulty for playing the game as you are easier to detect and movement becomes much harder while in this state. However, staying in light sources will make it easier for them to find you... I HIGHLY recommend this game to anyone looking for a thrill, alone or with friends. I also suggest playing in darkness with a headset on for maximum effects. This game is NOT for the faint of heart; do not play with winning as your goal.

												A fascinating little game.  At its absolute best, it delivers an exceedingly unsettling experience; at some point, you'll almost certainly find yourself cowering in a dark corner hoping desperately that something doesn't kill you and balancing the warm comfort of a candle against the risk something will come around the corner and rip your face off.  At its worst, it's a slow puzzler with sometimes-illogical requirements.Still, as a short, play-it-in-two-solid-sittings game, it's hard to top the  feel it delivers.  Well worth the 6-8 hours it'll take to finish.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2015
												I found out about this game through a review in PC Gamer magazine. I'll be the first to admit that I was skeptical about the mechanics (no weapons? what!?) but they are the key to the terror of this game. In any other scary game, you can just whip out a plasma cannon to destroy the things that scare you. In this game, all you can do is cower in fear and hide. This key mechanic, whereby you are rewarded for hiding raises the fear levels unlike anything I have ever played. When you round a corner in some dank, dark castle sub-floor and hear an inhuman growl, I guarantee you will soil your pants. The game itself oozes atmosphere, and it even encourages you to play in the dark with headphones on. This game is absolute ART that will TERRIFY you. I tell people all the time, "Amnesia makes Dead Space feel like a walk through a sunny, butterfly-filled meadow." There were literally moments where I had to step away from it to gather myself, it is THAT SCARY. Do yourself a favor and GET THIS GAME!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2015
												Rejuvenating survival horror. Perfect, endlessly unsettling sound design. Horrifying environments. Pure chilling Lovecraftian narrative told and unearthed in a consistently engaging manner. Puzzles that are simple enough to not become frustrating and challenging enough to not feel like pointless busywork. An unshakeable feeling of being chased and even in the dingiest corners being constantly out in the open and exposed to danger. Hiding from monsters that more often than not aren't there, abusing every inch of your imagination, and when they are there delivering terrifying sequences of frantic escape slamming doors behind you and terrified hiding cowering into walls desperately trying not to be seen, having to balance attempts at avoiding them with your dwindling sanity in the dark. Leaping from box to box in a flooded room avoiding the invisible creature that waits in the water, and the panicked rush to safety when you inevitably slip and hear the splashing rapidly approaching behind you. Lighting, sanity and "flight not fight" mechanics that have impacted so much in the five years since its release, making it hard to imagine the horror landscape of the 2010s without it. The defining horror game of the decade so far.

												I would be hard pressed to find any actual problems with Amnesia: The Dark Descent. The music, atmosphere, graphics, voice acting... it all comes together to create an experience that is positively terrifying. Until the Prison part that is. For some reason, by the time you reach the end of the Prison segment (which is the scariest area of the game), all tension deflates. Probably due to the fact, that anyone who pays attention will figure out the simple and heavily scripted enemy AI. While the story remains interesting and the atmosphere is still fantastic, the experience becomes more of the same. It is a great game though and everyone should play it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 18, 2013
												Amnesia is a survival horror/adventure game hybrid with a great emphasis on tension and expectations.The main meat of Amnesia is exploring a hollow Polish castle while trying to recover the protagonist's lost memories. During the adventure you will have to secure both your sanity (which can indeed drop in front of strange sights and award you a game over) and your personal health (which can be depleted by attacks and other hazards).The horror aspects of Amnesia are mainly jump scares and the odd sensation that something is going to happen to you, eventually. While some people may not fall for these scaring tricks, Amnesia is nevertheless able to keep up the tension for the whole ride.The featured puzzles are neither intuitive nor incredibly hard, allowing you to navigate the various levels without the preoccupation of getting stuck for minutes for a single tricky riddleRegarding the level design in Amnesia, one must notice how easy can be to provide the player with imaginative, hollow, scaring environments without deploying elaborate graphical marvels. And this while keeping the game beautiful to look at, so to speak.The only questionable feature of the game are the monsters themselves: while dangerous in their own right and used very cleverly by the developers to add to the paranoia, they are apparently not very capable at hunting you down. It's indeed possible to evade them with ease with a basic stealth approach and sometimes they even tend to get stuck trying to reach you.All in all, a more than worthy indie title, with a clever usage of atmosphere for mind-breaking effects and scenary porn abound

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2013
												For good or bad, video games have trained us to expect and desire violence in our entertainment. We start up a new title, especially action or horror, looking for a gun or a shovel or some blunt object so we can handle the hordes of enemies surely coming our way. When a game not only removes straight-forward combat but takes all fighting options off the table, the fear is very real. Amnesia's design is masterful. This is a game that MUST be played in a dark room, with the headphones on. You cannot defeat the grotesques that haunt the castle, so look for some good places to hide. The visuals are incredibly disturbing and suit the game well, and there's a lively community of modders crafting their own tales of mystery and terror. If you're a horror fan, you owe it to yourself to play Amnesia. Just be prepared to stay awake until dawn.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
												This game. This game is genius. There is no other way to describe it. Amnesia excels beyond any other game at making you feel completely helpless. Monsters? Yes. But weapons? A big fat NO. The only way you stay alive is by evading and hiding from monsters. And really, the scariness of Amnesia is not the monsters, but the lack thereof. It's the moments when you're walking through a completely silent hallway and your lantern oil runs out that are the scariest. I don't have any other words besides genius to describe this amazing work. Buy this game. You will be scared out of your wits at times, but when you finish the game as I did, you will realize its sheer genius.Well done, Frictional Games! A big salute goes out to you for this work of art!

content:
Posted: March 26, 2013
												I will be the first to say that some of the scares in this game are cheap and the programing is pretty predictable at times. Even when you know that sound you heard in one room is nothing, but that corner that is silent is most likely more dangerous, you still get a bit nervous. Honestly, this is probably one of the best and scariest horror games out there. Most people love this game, and it is easy to see why. You will spend most of the gameplay solving puzzles, and half way through the game you will find yourself hiding from monsters a lot. Even so, there are a few curve balls thrown into the game to make it feel fresh. One of my favorite disturbing moments in the game was when I had to try to get away from an invisible water creature by throwing remains acrossed the room hoping that it would go after that instead of me. This game is disturbing, frightening, and chilling, with a great story to boot. Fans of the horror genre will love this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 4, 2016
												A sweet, super short and absolutely spoiler-free review and opinion on the game Amnesia: The Dark Descent by Frictional Games.Close your door, shut down the lights and let the darkness sink in... The only visible light source being the computer monitor. The most rewarding experience will only be achievable in total darkness. Amnesia: The Dark Descent will take care of the rest.As a horror game this gets a lot of things right with just only a handful of annoyances mixed in. The game is definitely recommendable to anyone who is able to handle a lot of spooks and many more jump scares.The game goes even as far as planting some philosophical and truly thought provoking concepts in players head. So after one has beaten the game the memories about the “descending” aren’t necessarily the scary bits and pieces but the moments when the thoughts about “right” and “wrong” start to have debates in players mind. That’s perhaps the most rewarding aspect of the whole packet.My IGN-score: 8.5 / 10***SPOILERS (for those who really want to have a ‘clean’ experience)***Pros:- enjoyable surroundings- atmosphere- the dance of light and darkness (to put it nicely ^_^)Cons:- low resolution textures (the game is nearly seven years old so hardly surprising)- not enough notes, diaries etc to read (completely subjective viewpoint)- less appealing in the end (ok, this one is kinda a stretch {as I said there isn't much to criticise})

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2016
												Amnesia: The Dark Descent is a revivification of the atmospheric horror game. Unable to fight the abominations that stalk you, Amnesia leaves you alone in a gritty atmospheric, slowly turning horrific, setting that pushes you toward finding the answers to your ailment, Amnesia. The game focuses on a few game-play mechanics such as health, mental health (though I believe is called insanity in the game), and finding what are essentially keys for the next zone (though are often items and puzzles) while for the most part being actively stalked by monsters. Some of the most notable elements of the game-play are the mental health meter and its gripping pacing. The mental health in the game involves your ability to stay in the light and avoid gazing at monsters for too long. The second being probably the most important feature. Once the unknown becomes the known it becomes a lot less frightful, so having a game-play mechanic that punishes the unknown becoming known it incredibly smart and well done and it is sufficient enough to last almost the entire game (the later areas somewhat abandon this concept, and it becomes a lot less scary for doing so). Until the end of the game it does a good job of pacing areas of horror and peace, though unannounced to the player, and never once did I feel cheated by the monsters. Overall I would suggest Amnesia to anyone who is looking for a dark, gripping, and atmospheric horror game that will last you a couple of days (approximately 8 hours of content).

content:
Posted: August 15, 2016
												Pretty good game! It's very atmospheric and I love how the history of the character gets revealed little by little, which is kinda expected every time a game/movie/book has amnesia in it. Although this is a horror game, it's not filled with jumpscares. I remember maybe 2 throughout the entire game. The rest of the horror comes from the soundtrack, the ambience, and the layout of the castle (those loooong hallways or all of the corners are great to add suspense). The puzzles are pretty fun. None of them are difficult, which is a bit disappointing, but it also makes it so that you won't get stuck for very long any any one spot.I highly recommend this game, and I'm not usually a fan of horror.

I honestly didn't progressed that much to the game because I quitted, the more I played it the more I was getting stressed and tense about it so I decided that Amnesia The Dark Descent is too much for me too handle in an emotional standpoint. That said, this game is great and everyone should try it but be warned that you might end up like me or you might end up experiencing one of the most compelling and immersive games ever in the history of gaming.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2015
												Amnesia: The Dark Descent is one of the best horror-survival games I've ever played. The ominous ambiance, the opressive feeling of helplessness, rotting decay, and sudden rush of adrenaline... it's even better than years ago, when it scared the heck out of me. What scared me the most back then, is that you're trying to be calm in your darkened room with your headphones and wet hands grabbing the mouse, when something makes you jump and race away. You NEED this game, not only because it's superbly designed, but for the originality of it, in a genre that has become rather dull. The graphics have not aged well, but the complexity of the game remains just the same. It took me two years to finish it the first time, even when  it's a long game... but because I couldn't bear the scares quite often. This time... I'm ready.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18
												Amnesia is a pants sh*tting experience (nearly) throughout the whole game. It revived survival horror and brought it into the mainstream......however......once you discover the pattern behind the monster encounters, it's over. As in, the tension disappears and the fear factor becomes non-existent. In addition, the main protagonist's reactions are way overdone. He gets a seizure and hyperventilates each time a book falls off the shelf. It's not scary, it destroys immersion and makes the protagonist seem like a total wuss, especially when my own reaction to said book is a resounding 'meh'. I recommend it still since, other than horror, it can be an entertaining adventure game.For those curious, I will write about the pattern down below.*SPOILERS*It's not hard to discover the pattern, unfortunately.- The monster spawns are entirely scripted. They spawn very often once you take a puzzle item or solve a puzzle. Rarely when you enter a room.- To prevent from being killed, close the door to the room the puzzle or item are in before doing what you need to do. When the monster spawns, it starts attacking the door and gives you time to hide.- To hide, just break the line of sight. You don't even have to enter a dark area.- Keep being hidden until the monster music stops playing. Once this occurs, the monster literally despawned, i.e. it vanished, disappeared. You can now run around freely until a next monster spawns.There are one or two exceptions where the monster is already there, has a defined patrol route, and does not despawn.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2013
												Truly a worthy successor to the Penumbra Series and vastly more scary, Dark Descent is DAMN good.ScaresThis game is scary as all hell if you follow the directions (play at night or in the darkest room available, use headphone with good volume level, allow no distractions). From start the finish you feel your own insanity meter spiraling out of control as you immerse yourself into the atmosphere.. This game will have you begging for a brightly-lit room in which to collect your sanity before pressing on.PuzzlesThere are a solid amount of puzzles that are typically never obvious (A Machine for Pigs, I'm looking at you). There are also many items to collect and use throughout the game (A Machine for Pigs, I'm looking at you again). They also act as a contrast to the scary sections of the game, allowing yourself to take a break from being insane.Plot / StoryThe story takes a back-seat to nothing and aligns with what I would expect coming from the Penumbra series. If you are interested, the game provides a wealth of back-stories and side-stories to explore.Other Stuff- Game's good- You should buy it and play it- If you like it you should go buy the Penumbra series - 3 games for cheap!

content:
Posted: April 4, 2016
												Alrighty, another review! Amnesia: The Dark Descent is one of those games that you see everywhere and wonder how creepy/eerie/scary it might be. Well you just come to the right place if you want to either♥♥♥♥♥♥your pants or learn a fascinating yet gory story. You wake up as Daniel and have no recolation as to where or how you got to where you are when waking up. As the story progresses (and I will try not to have any spoilers) you pick up notes and random journal entries that you had written before passing out and waking up in the beginning. As your memory gets better, you realize you had been working for an evil mastermind named Alexander who kidnapps victims and tortures them to be "experiments". Once found out this, you do whatever you can to stop Alexander. The rest is up to you to find out, besides everyone likes suprises. Now, when playing this game I was scared within 10 minutes of playing because of the creepy music, random voices and noises, and of course visuals which I will not spoil. If you turn your sound off completely though, it doesn't phase me one bit. So basically, if you are chicken♥♥♥♥♥♥then you should turn off your sound so you can focus on the main objective instead of focusing on what pair of underwear you need to wash from playing this. In all seriousness though, I would only reccomend someone who has a strong stomach since most of the game is quite gory and if dissassembled body parts freak you out then you shouldn't even be playing this game. I would like to add is that this game is medium length which I don't mind. I wish it was slightly longer but you can only do so much with a story and a horror game. Something to also add, this game has medium to hard difficulty puzzles which some had taken me days to figure out. So if you are one to rush and add cheats to the game well you are out of luck buddy because there are no cheats except for walkthroughs on the game online, and you must have patience. I would rate this game a 8/10 and reccomend anyone 16+

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 18, 2013
												Amnesia is a survival horror/adventure game hybrid with a great emphasis on tension and expectations.The main meat of Amnesia is exploring a hollow Polish castle while trying to recover the protagonist's lost memories. During the adventure you will have to secure both your sanity (which can indeed drop in front of strange sights and award you a game over) and your personal health (which can be depleted by attacks and other hazards).The horror aspects of Amnesia are mainly jump scares and the odd sensation that something is going to happen to you, eventually. While some people may not fall for these scaring tricks, Amnesia is nevertheless able to keep up the tension for the whole ride.The featured puzzles are neither intuitive nor incredibly hard, allowing you to navigate the various levels without the preoccupation of getting stuck for minutes for a single tricky riddleRegarding the level design in Amnesia, one must notice how easy can be to provide the player with imaginative, hollow, scaring environments without deploying elaborate graphical marvels. And this while keeping the game beautiful to look at, so to speak.The only questionable feature of the game are the monsters themselves: while dangerous in their own right and used very cleverly by the developers to add to the paranoia, they are apparently not very capable at hunting you down. It's indeed possible to evade them with ease with a basic stealth approach and sometimes they even tend to get stuck trying to reach you.All in all, a more than worthy indie title, with a clever usage of atmosphere for mind-breaking effects and scenary porn abound

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2013
												Amnesia: The Dark Descent is worth a look if you like your horror. It's beautiful in style, soundtrack (and voice acting) and mood, and really gets you going if you play it at night. And you really should play it at night, because not only are you going to get a better scare in dim darkness, your many Steam friends will certainly be judging the character of a person who dilutes their fear to a manageable level.Without revealing too much, the storyline concerns the personification and mind of Daniel: a nyctophobic archaeologist (I know) who has left himself a note to kill the owner of Brennenburg Castle. More of the storyline is discovered when you find notes that Daniel has written for himself and pages of his diary. Piece by piece the story takes shape and gives you something to think about while treading the flagstones through the rooms.The gameplay revolves around Daniel solving puzzles, working machinery and occasionally running for his life. Or more to the point his sanity; not only do you have to keep your health up, you must defend your mind too. Standing around in the dark or activating something terrifying will drain away your will to live, and it means you must find or create sources of light to keep the insanity pangs at bay. The best aspect of the game of course is the atmosphere created when the shadow comes to hunt you down. You don’t see the monster very much, but at all times you’re on edge ready for when it strikes. And when the shadow does show up you’re completely clueless as to how to evade it, which makes Amnesia: The Dark Descent one of the best horror games, simply because the fear is happening in your own mind as opposed to jump-scares on the screen, and who knows what your mind can conjure up when it takes a trip into Amnesia…

content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												So. Much. Mystery. Amnesia: The Dark Descent is by no means child's play, and I do not recommend it to the light-hearted. It's thick. Very thick. And the last eigth or so of the campaign is rather morbib. But if you're wanting an edge-of-your-seat game, this nailed it. Of course, I approached it wanting what it had to offer: mystery, thrill, and scare--and it delivered quite well. If you liked the Myst series, Amnesia brings about a whole new depth to venturing the unknown. Quite honestly, I had to buy the sequel the day after I finished it just to suffice my hunger for what The Dark Descent had given me--I can only hope The Machine for Pigs is half as good.UPDATE: It is. The Machine for Pigs has a story definitely worth playing, but I also admire the mechanics of The Dark Descent more. Also, I just can't get past how awesome the sound is in both. Seriously messes with the dead xD

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
												This horror game is one for the ages. It has the feeling of eerie aloneness, and at the same time making you feel as though you are being watched! This is a horror game like no other; because you can't fight back... only run, hide, and pray you're not found. You are a character named Daniel and you are trying to kill Alexander of Brennenburg. Alone the way you are aided with the flashbacks, notes, and voice of your former self. You're never safe. There is a shadow following you, and making it nearly impossible to accomplish your goal. It ranges from red slime to monsters out of your worst nightmares in this game. If you search, you will find lanterns, oil, tinderboxes, sanity potion and items that will help you progress in the game, be that keys, supplies to form acid to melt the red slime, ETC. It you are into games that are not only scary, but run a goal all at the same time, this is the game for you! So... can you kill Alexander and make it out alive; or die trying?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
												If you're any bit active in the gaming community, you've probably heard about this game. You've also probably heard that it is quite scary as well. You'd be right. Not only does this game contain fear, but it also contains heart. No, it's not a thinly or thickly veiled romance game. I mean, the developers at Frictional Games imbued their mind and body energy into this game and you notice this in the game with the optional commentary nodes. I never thought I'd say this, but a company besides Valve actually had really great commentary. They put in a ton of attention to detail and did a spectacular job in creating a world where immersion is as easy as W, A, S, D, and Space. The gameplay provides a nice balance of light and dark, where sanity, light, and not getting killed are resources. The game also makes your imagination your enemy, until you actually encounter one of the many Gatherers of Brennenburg Castle, and if you take enough time to get a clear glimpse of one, it'll rip your face off and use it as a book cover.  Daniel, Alexander, and Agrippa are all solid with good voices, the story is interesting and relevant to what you're doing, there's no side quest ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, and text documents provide well-needed info as how Daniel got into this predicament and how to solve some of the puzzles. Metacritic gave this game an 85/100 and that's garbage. They only had a few people and made a game 10 times scarier than most mainstream titles! In short, this game is scary, immersive, tells a good story, puzzle elements, stealth, and with the custom stories feature, offers a near-limitless amount of gameplay. Nearly♥♥♥♥♥♥my-trousers/10, 5 stars.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2013
												Amnesia: The Dark Descent is worth a look if you like your horror. It's beautiful in style, soundtrack (and voice acting) and mood, and really gets you going if you play it at night. And you really should play it at night, because not only are you going to get a better scare in dim darkness, your many Steam friends will certainly be judging the character of a person who dilutes their fear to a manageable level.Without revealing too much, the storyline concerns the personification and mind of Daniel: a nyctophobic archaeologist (I know) who has left himself a note to kill the owner of Brennenburg Castle. More of the storyline is discovered when you find notes that Daniel has written for himself and pages of his diary. Piece by piece the story takes shape and gives you something to think about while treading the flagstones through the rooms.The gameplay revolves around Daniel solving puzzles, working machinery and occasionally running for his life. Or more to the point his sanity; not only do you have to keep your health up, you must defend your mind too. Standing around in the dark or activating something terrifying will drain away your will to live, and it means you must find or create sources of light to keep the insanity pangs at bay. The best aspect of the game of course is the atmosphere created when the shadow comes to hunt you down. You don’t see the monster very much, but at all times you’re on edge ready for when it strikes. And when the shadow does show up you’re completely clueless as to how to evade it, which makes Amnesia: The Dark Descent one of the best horror games, simply because the fear is happening in your own mind as opposed to jump-scares on the screen, and who knows what your mind can conjure up when it takes a trip into Amnesia…

content:
Posted: March 18, 2014
												OMG! This game is freaky as shiznit.  The graphics/locales, sound/music, enemies with the gashed/wrenched open mouths, the fleshy darkness taking over the game world occaisonally making it feel reminiscent of the otherwold in the earlier Silent Hill games, and the revelation of what Alexander had you doing to save yourself from said darkness, etc. all make this game an unforgettable experience. Also, the environmental puzzles are challenging to a fault, but in no way too challenging, and they feel like they are an integral part of the game's story/progression.If you haven't already played this yet then you need to do so ASAP!!  It should only take about 6-8 hrs real world time to beat it, so it doesn't feel like a cumbersome untertaking, especially if you're strapped for time, but also short enough to possible make you want to go back and play it again at a later date.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
												Pros:Interesting story - The character you play as (Daniel) lost his memory, but a note he left to himself describes that he has to kill this evil man at the very bottom of this castle, deep in the dungeons. Along the way, you collect more of Daniel's diary and uncover the reason behind why this man needs to be dealt with.Creepy setting - The castle of Brennenburg is quite scary because the guy who owns this place is a horrible person and the story within this castle makes it all that much creepier. Some areas you come across make you not want to take another step forward because you know that there is some scary events that are about to go down in this area that you are about to progress through.Scary monsters - These 'servants' are freaky as hell, especially because you can't fight them back. You have to hide in the darkness so that they do not see you.Puzzles - I'd hate to admit it but I had to look up a few sections because I had no idea what to do. But there was one part where something you have to do to progress is so random that you would never guess unless you are some kind of strange genius.Music - When servants see you and are headed your way, the music really adds fear to the situation, like a scary movie in theaters. The music really matches this abandoned castle, because it makes you feel like you are alone, but you know you are not alone.Gameplay - Daniel loses his sanity the longer you are in the darkness...you need to reach lit areas to progress. You have to limit how many candles/torches you can light because you don't collect many tinderboxes. And if you light hallways, it could mean the death of you because if the servants see you and chase you down the hallway, they will still see you in this light and chase you all the way through. It is all made worse because you CANNOT FIGHT BACK!Scariness - OK, this is the scariest game I've played, and I'll tell you why. The developers didn't rely on cheap jump scares. They put in pure scary content, the monsters ('servants') are scarier than all hell, you panic when you even hear one of these creatures. When you run out of lighting resources (tinderboxes and lantern oil), you panic. When you enter certain areas, you know you are going to encounter these things just by looking through the entrance.Cons:Voice Acting - The voice acting in this game is subpar. Yes I understand that this isn't an A-list game, but you can get some better voice acting in here.Character Design - Every body except the servants in this game are complete♥♥♥♥♥♥ The living humans you come across in this game have horrible design. The dead humans you come across in this game have horrible design. I know this is a strange thing to point out, but the naked bodies in this game are made like♥♥♥♥♥♥ The male bodies' junk is just a cylindrical lump on the body. My point is, if you can't make a body part right, cover it up, especially if it is an unessiantial body part to look at, like a♥♥♥♥♥♥♥The Ending - I won't spoil anything but I'll throw spoiler tags on it anyway...  The ending is quick, and then just done with. Roll credits Verdict:Even though this game has some issues, it is still a good game. You'll mainly enjoy it for the scares though, as the voices and graphics kill your vibe outside of the parts where you are running or hiding from the servants. This game is worth full price because it is only $20, and the amount of scary content you get in this game is worth it. It also has a decent replay value to it because you can get your friends to play this, and watch them spaz out while they play it. Recommended to anybody looking for some good scares.My rating: 6/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												Oh, Amnesia: The Dark Descent. Where could I begin? Coming from somebody who often frequents games in the horror genre, I can safely say this is the most terrifying game I have ever played. The thing about Amnesia is that even when there is no danger, the game still manages to install a feeling of dread into your mind for roughly 95% of the entire experience. The notes that can be read in the game, while not necessary to understand the story, add so much to the atmosphere. This game does not rely on cheap jumpscares, but when the moments of danger do come, they are presented in such a way in which you do not just jump in your seat for a second and laugh it off, but rather your heart starts to pound as you run down corridors and try to find a place to hide. Another great aspect of this game (which has unfortunately been copied, and badly, many times now) is that you have absolutely no means to defend yourself from the monsters, and you can only hope you can either outrun them (You can't) or hope you can't be seen in your hiding spot. All in all, I would say that Amnesia delivers a great story, near perfect atmosphere, and scares that will leave you crying for your mommy. Amnesia: The Dark Descent represents the best of the horror genre, and is a mix of great pacing, atmosphere, storytelling, graphics, and pure, bitter dread. I would recommend this game to basically anybody who loves the thrill of being scared, or anybody just looking for a new experience that differs from other games in general. 10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
												If you're looking to make the clothes beneath your stomach nice and damp, go somewhere else........but if you're looking for a nice atmospheric game that will grip you with its story, and make you want to explore and experience: this is the game for you. Cause this game is ALL about your feeling of "What the hell is going on?", and by looking around you and finding pages from your diary you slowly uncover what has happened in this castle. Speaking of castle, it IS a rather spooky castle: I found myself jumping more from the creeks and the wind working on the old structure than the actual monsters, and some rooms are just messed-up fun.This game also has a great community for mods and custom maps, so this game has high replayability and length (some of the custom content might even manage to scare you...)There are some let-downs though, the most notable being the tediousness of the puzzles. If this game had any more puzzles, I'd call it Portal 3. The monsters not really being more than an inconvenience is also a minus, and a system were you slowly lose your sanity by not being close to light is just annoying: it ruins the atmosphere to have to lift your lantern every 3 meters. Overall it's a nice, tense experience. Having a mod community is ALWAYS a big plus for me. But it's not a great horror game. It may work nicely as your first horror game, if you're too afraid to try others.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 2, 2015
												I don't really find myself to be a fan of the horror genre.  That being said, I have somehow ended up with many different horror games, including Dead Space, Outlast, the FEAR series, and, of course, this game.  Of the games I listed, Amnesia: The Dark Descent has to be my favorite.  The atmoshpere is perfect throughout the game, especially in areas such as the Prison and the Choir.  There are a few jump scares throughout the game, which I don't like as much, but are fine in horror when limited, I just don't like the games that are completely based on them.  Amnesia is not one of these games, I find the atmosphere and the setting to be the main part of the horror, along with the stealth aspect of the game, where the main character has to hide in order to survive.  There is no charging through this game, the player must take their time in order to progress, but they cannot be too slow, otherwise the sanity bar drains, and the game gets creepier, hallucinations occur more, and sometimes the game actually changes.The steam version includes the Justine Expansion, an hour long expansion with the luxury of choice in it, do you wanna be a jerk and let the people die, or save them?  It also includes a little thing called *Remember*, which I have not tried yet.  Both can be accessed through the settings configuration tool that is accessed during launchup.Positives:- Horror aspect not based on jump scares, like Slender was.- It's actually creepy, and the environment is just unsettling.- There is the perfect amount of the survival aspect- Monsters are an actual danger, and not just for appearence.  The monsters cannot be killed, with the exception of the water monster- the water monster can be killed by bashing it over and over with a box or barrel, until the yellowish blood can be seen and the activity stops.- Custom Stories- It gave me 8 hours of gameplay, which is pretty good for a linear horror game.Negatives:- I find there to be a lack of replayability in the game.  I've beaten it once, and I don't really need to play it again.  That being said, I'm attempting a speed run soon.  I basically just contradicted myself there, but I'm not gonna play it again without some sort of challenge for myselfHow well does it run?This game is surprisingly taxing, for it basically being darkness, with a few monsters thrown into it.  I have my crappy Dell Laptop (CPU-i-7 3612QM Quad Core 2.1 GHz, RAM-8 GB DDR3, Graphics-Intel HD 4000, Screen-1600x900) running this game on custom settings at 30 FPS.My settings:Texture Filter: BilinearSSAO- On, Resolution-Medium, Samples-8Edge Smooth- OnWorld Reflection- OnAnisotropy- 8xParallax- OnIt may be that my settings are too high for the computer, but I'm so used to 30 FPS that it isn't a big deal.  This will run better on a better computer with a dedicated GPU.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2011
												*The* scariest game I've ever played. Play through the whole thing alone in the dark with headphones on, and you're a braver man than I.This title was the follow up to Frictional's Penumbra series, and continues the same style of play. However, unlike Penumbra where the darkness was your friend, it's an ever-present threat in Amnesia. Staying in the dark for too long will slowly scratch away at your sanity, causing you to see and hear things that aren't there. Insanity causes your character to behave erratically, essentially turning you into walking monster pheromone.Seeing as lantern oil and tinderboxes are in limited supply, this serves to drive the player forward through the game.The sound design is really fantastic, the graphics are admirable and the environment and monsters are diabolically nightmarish. The only thing keeping this from being a perfect horror title are some simple gameplay exploits.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2012
												This game is a true masterpiece. Disturbing, mind-blowingly scary and more intense than your granny on drugs and skates. Take control of, and see through the eyes of Daniel, an English archeologist who suddenly finds himself trapped inside the huge, dark and seemingly haunted castle of Brennenburg. Waking up, remembering nothing about his former self, Daniel emerges out on an adventure he won't soon forget...You'll wish you never bought the game, yet you will get scared, and you will like it. You'll be completely glued to the screen for hours, trying to find the correct path, or the right set of rods for that damned broken elevator. Monsters will be chasing you, and all you have to "defend" yourself with is a lamp, with barely enough oil to get you through sticky situations. The darkness will swallow you, and your sanity will be tested both inside and outside the game.In conclusion, you'll♥♥♥♥♥♥brix, and you'll♥♥♥♥♥♥'em hard! Totally worth the low sum of 30 bucks.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												Somewhere between all the YouTube wecams and mindless fans blindly praising Amnesia, is a game that I don't think quite lives up to the hype as the "scariest game of all time," but is still pretty damn good.As we all know, the game takes place in a deserted castle and you play as Daniel, a man who awakes with amnesia. As you wander around the castle for the next few hours, you'll learn about the history of both the castle and it's caretaker, and Daniel's intentions for being there. The game is excellent at building tension and atmosphere, you will hold your breath many times while walking the halls of the castle.The gameplay is where some of the problems begin to arise. I just found the game to be a little too forgiving. The tinderbox system is pretty much broken; I had a ridiculous number of them at the end of the game, somewhere in the 20s. The sanity meter is interesting enough, but I never really felt threatened if it got to a high level. If the meter gets too high, Daniel will pass out and awake after a few seconds. This happened once or twice during my playthrough, but nothing seemed to change afterwards. However, the absolute worst aspect is the enemy AI; Once you figure out the secret of their pathfinding and realize that they only stick to certain areas, the game becomes a breeze, and all feelings of horror and fear are lost. The puzzles aren't very tricky, but I did have to look up where to go once (I had to stack boxes because there was a hatch on a cieling... go figure).So while Amnesia does capture a constant feeling of dread, you can only be as scared from the game as you want to be. It makes no attempt to hide that it is in fact, just a game.Do I recommend Amnesia: The Dark Descent? Yes, to every horror fan. Old school horror fanatics will be pleased by this treat, and younger fans will scream at their Twitch followers.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2016
												First off, I've played this game offline as well so I probably have around 70-80+ hours into this game as of this date.Unless you get scared REALLY easily, this isn't a terrifying game. Where the horror lies is in the atmosphere. You feel isolated, yet always with that sensation that someone, or something is watching you... I could go on and on about what I love about this game. I really could. It has aged wonderfully. The voice acting is spot on. The music is amazing and really sets the mood. No weapons, nothing to defend yourself; it is a true psychological survival horror. The custom story feature extends the replayability considerably. No game is perfect though, and Amnesia needs patches, which unfortunately it will probably never receive. I recently completed a no lantern/tinderbox run and got stuck in a wall. There are areas in the game where such a "feature" can be exploited for speed runs, but that was not one of them! And in many areas if you die enough times, the enemies will not respawn... go ahead and exploit that, you cheater. :P

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2011
												Amnesia: The Dark Descent pits you against occult, nightmarish horrors and the terror of darkness. The nice twist is that it does this by taking away from you the things you always can depend on in your other games: your sanity, your ability to see your surroundings, and most importantly, your ability to fight and defend yourself. You will have to hide and flee in order to survive. If you have the power to suspend disbelief, and enjoy the feeling that something is watching you from the shadows, this is a game that is not to be missed.

content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
												So you want a horror game? You've come to the right place. Amnesia is full of scares of all kinds, and the nearly unlimited fan-made custom stories only increase the terror. If you are a true horror fan, you MUST play this game. It is not a suggestion; it is a   requirement. And if you are not a horror fan, why not give it a try? (I just want to see you jump in fright, honestly.) Basically, this game is great for scares (of all varieties: tense atmosphere, chase scenes, and of course, jumpscares). However, I feel it is my duty to speak of the bad parts of Amnesia. Firstly, and most importantly, nobody in the game wears clothes. They are also all male. I don't know why the developers decided to do this, but they did. So, be warned. Male anatomy is unavoidable in this game. Secondly, there is a heavy theme of torture in this game. I don't like it, nobody really does. But it does increase the sense of fright, and nothing is actually shown (nothing realistic, at least). Other than that, this game is ridiculously cool. Oh, and one more thing. The only weapon you have... is stealth, and if that fails, running. You are helpless against the monsters that pursue you, which goes a long way towards increasing the scare level. Go buy this game now, if you are hungry for horror.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
												A wonderfully, terrifying experience.Turn off the lights, put your headphones on and enter the world of Amnesia. The ambiance of Amnesia provides a level of immersion seldom presented in a game. Every element, particularly the sound, is crafted with care and detail. The game doesn't utilize jump scares or gore, but tension as a way to convey the fear and crumbling sanity of the protagonist. The game play is simple, as you are provided no weapons (further aiding a  feeling of helplessness) and do not expect any innovative mechanics. In general, the game is like a warm bath of dread. Just let the uneasiness sink in and enjoy the calming descent into madness.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2015
												Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!This is a Atmospheric Horror  game.Interface/Menu/SettingsYou can have multiple Profile Save slots.There is only a Master volume Bar and You can change the number between 1 and 10.There are MANY different resolution sizes.You can play this game fullscreen or windowed mode.There is a Gamma(Brightness) Bar.There are some Different languages.You can use your xbox controller.About the game.You are playing with a character that has Amnesia. You are wandering in some kind of castle finding for clues and items. You interact with objects on the way you will also do in real life. Darkness is the most common enemy in this game. If standing too long in the darkness, Your sanity will slowly drain. You have a health bar and sanity bar. The game has a deep storyline and following clues and solving things will increase your sanity bar. You can find Oil and tinderboxes to create some light in the room. You are able to bring and carry around an oil Lantern. Each time you light up a candle with a tinderbox, it will consume 1 dose.You can find Commentary developer icons (Telling you background details about the game). You can turn this off however.Voiced over with Subtitles.Great Atmosphere.Great deep story and background story details.Realistic interacting with objects but sometimes really buggy.Character walks slow.Great Puzzles.Other things.No Jumpscares! AS A HORROR GAME SHOULD BE!Some of the Voice acting from the "Commentery developer icons" are difficult to understand. Because of Accent or microphone quality.Developers commentary COULD SPOIL THINGS!-------------------I Give this game a 7/10

content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												I would like to start this review by pointing out that I do not like horror games or horror in general.HOWEVER.This game blew my mind when I played it. It has the perfect atmosphere, an actual storyline (which not many horror games can claim to have) and no pathetic, all-of-a-sudden jumpscares out of nowhere. With that being said, you are on the edge of your seat the whole game, waiting for something to jump out from the shadows. I especially like the "sanity" implentemation, giving another meter to watch out for.This is the only horror game I have ever truly liked, as a game, and as a story. Definitely give this one a try, people.

												A wonderfully, terrifying experience.Turn off the lights, put your headphones on and enter the world of Amnesia. The ambiance of Amnesia provides a level of immersion seldom presented in a game. Every element, particularly the sound, is crafted with care and detail. The game doesn't utilize jump scares or gore, but tension as a way to convey the fear and crumbling sanity of the protagonist. The game play is simple, as you are provided no weapons (further aiding a  feeling of helplessness) and do not expect any innovative mechanics. In general, the game is like a warm bath of dread. Just let the uneasiness sink in and enjoy the calming descent into madness.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
												This is one of the scariest games in recent memory. The loading screen recommends you turn the lights off and play with headphones, something I'll strongly echo. Amnesia: The Dark Descent's puzzles aren't especially impressive and the voice acting can range from convincing to goofy, but the atmosphere Frictional has infused into the experience is as powerful as they come. It's a tale of terror that's menacing and disturbing from the very first moments, and only amplifies the further you progress. Any fan of horror, every Lovecraft fan, and any with even a hint of curiosity should give Amnesia a shot!!In Frictional Games' Amnesia: The Dark Descent, you get no gun. When a gruesome shambling creature rounds a corner on wobbly knees and its yawning rictus comes into focus, you can only succumb to its onslaught or flee in terror, hoping the shadows will provide safe haven. It plays more like a first-person adventure game than anything else, and borrows many of the environmental manipulation mechanics of Frictional's previous Penumbra series. It's a fairly short game, but one that's near impossible to forget.What follows is a tale told mostly in flashback as you' re beset by ghostly visions and uncover journal entries on dimly lit desks that tell of scientific expeditions that lead to the discovery of ancient terrors. By itself the story is strong enough, and told effectively assuming you take the time to explore and pick up a majority of the notes. Yet what really adds a quality of unsettling authenticity to the tale is the unshakeable feeling of pursuit and inevitability of some kind of horrific climax.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												This is an amazing horror game that builds up tension like Slender, has jump scares like Outlast, and an amazing story line such as The Last of Us. The game is actually based off of true legends of Castle Brennenburg in Poland, the setting of the game. Amnesia is deep, and has recently been labeled as one of the top horror games ever made.The environment in this game is very fitting, and you can manipulate objects to your advantage. The monsters are creative and unique and the ambience is unbeatable. As you walk through castle Brennenburg, you can automatically tell that this was perfect for a horror story.This game is not straight forward all of the time though. There are puzzles designed to challenge the player, while panicking in fear of the next monster. Each part of the game can be taken at the gamer's own pace, depending on if you are a cautious player, or the run-in-head-first player. Another thing that is great about this game is that it does not shove plot into your face. You can choose to pick up the notes that are scattered around the castle, or ignore them to complete the game. There are bits though, that are crucial to the end of the game that are forced upon you. There is a total of two cut scenes, at the beginning and the end of the game; that is if you do not count the times you regain your memory. These are short, although quite frankly annoying and tedious. The game in itself has removed most of the problems, but can get glitchy at some points. Occasionally, one of the monsters will get stuck in a wall or you will have troubles with some of the items, but are easy to ignore. Over all this game is perfect for any horror gamer, but should be avoided if you do not enjoy puzzles. The ending is not one you should miss, and will bring you about 10 hours of nerve-wracking gametime.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												Easily one of the most rich, well-designed, and fun video games I've ever played.  As with SOMA, Frictional manages to create vast, believable worlds, dripping with atmosphere and immersed in story, and they do it without non-stop shooting of guns.  I anxiously await Frictional's next accomplishment, even if I have to wait years for it.I expected this game to be very scary -- there were a few moments, but once I got into the groove of the game, it was more of an exciting story to be a part of and less of a horrific experience.  I was fine with that.  I felt more genuine terror when playing SOMA.My only complaint, which resonates throughout the Frictional catalog for me, is that the puzzles are rather pedestrian.  I almost wish they were left out altogther, in favor of more story.  In contrast to SOMA, the monsters in this game did not detract from my abililty to explore, because they wandered so far away and were trivially easy to hide from.No matter.  My very highest recommendation.  Take the advice about turning off the lights and headphones for best possible atmosphere.  Soak it all in and be transported for a few wonderful hours.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
												If you're any bit active in the gaming community, you've probably heard about this game. You've also probably heard that it is quite scary as well. You'd be right. Not only does this game contain fear, but it also contains heart. No, it's not a thinly or thickly veiled romance game. I mean, the developers at Frictional Games imbued their mind and body energy into this game and you notice this in the game with the optional commentary nodes. I never thought I'd say this, but a company besides Valve actually had really great commentary. They put in a ton of attention to detail and did a spectacular job in creating a world where immersion is as easy as W, A, S, D, and Space. The gameplay provides a nice balance of light and dark, where sanity, light, and not getting killed are resources. The game also makes your imagination your enemy, until you actually encounter one of the many Gatherers of Brennenburg Castle, and if you take enough time to get a clear glimpse of one, it'll rip your face off and use it as a book cover.  Daniel, Alexander, and Agrippa are all solid with good voices, the story is interesting and relevant to what you're doing, there's no side quest ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, and text documents provide well-needed info as how Daniel got into this predicament and how to solve some of the puzzles. Metacritic gave this game an 85/100 and that's garbage. They only had a few people and made a game 10 times scarier than most mainstream titles! In short, this game is scary, immersive, tells a good story, puzzle elements, stealth, and with the custom stories feature, offers a near-limitless amount of gameplay. Nearly♥♥♥♥♥♥my-trousers/10, 5 stars.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2013
												Amnesia: The Dark Descent is worth a look if you like your horror. It's beautiful in style, soundtrack (and voice acting) and mood, and really gets you going if you play it at night. And you really should play it at night, because not only are you going to get a better scare in dim darkness, your many Steam friends will certainly be judging the character of a person who dilutes their fear to a manageable level.Without revealing too much, the storyline concerns the personification and mind of Daniel: a nyctophobic archaeologist (I know) who has left himself a note to kill the owner of Brennenburg Castle. More of the storyline is discovered when you find notes that Daniel has written for himself and pages of his diary. Piece by piece the story takes shape and gives you something to think about while treading the flagstones through the rooms.The gameplay revolves around Daniel solving puzzles, working machinery and occasionally running for his life. Or more to the point his sanity; not only do you have to keep your health up, you must defend your mind too. Standing around in the dark or activating something terrifying will drain away your will to live, and it means you must find or create sources of light to keep the insanity pangs at bay. The best aspect of the game of course is the atmosphere created when the shadow comes to hunt you down. You don’t see the monster very much, but at all times you’re on edge ready for when it strikes. And when the shadow does show up you’re completely clueless as to how to evade it, which makes Amnesia: The Dark Descent one of the best horror games, simply because the fear is happening in your own mind as opposed to jump-scares on the screen, and who knows what your mind can conjure up when it takes a trip into Amnesia…

content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
												Pros:Interesting story - The character you play as (Daniel) lost his memory, but a note he left to himself describes that he has to kill this evil man at the very bottom of this castle, deep in the dungeons. Along the way, you collect more of Daniel's diary and uncover the reason behind why this man needs to be dealt with.Creepy setting - The castle of Brennenburg is quite scary because the guy who owns this place is a horrible person and the story within this castle makes it all that much creepier. Some areas you come across make you not want to take another step forward because you know that there is some scary events that are about to go down in this area that you are about to progress through.Scary monsters - These 'servants' are freaky as hell, especially because you can't fight them back. You have to hide in the darkness so that they do not see you.Puzzles - I'd hate to admit it but I had to look up a few sections because I had no idea what to do. But there was one part where something you have to do to progress is so random that you would never guess unless you are some kind of strange genius.Music - When servants see you and are headed your way, the music really adds fear to the situation, like a scary movie in theaters. The music really matches this abandoned castle, because it makes you feel like you are alone, but you know you are not alone.Gameplay - Daniel loses his sanity the longer you are in the darkness...you need to reach lit areas to progress. You have to limit how many candles/torches you can light because you don't collect many tinderboxes. And if you light hallways, it could mean the death of you because if the servants see you and chase you down the hallway, they will still see you in this light and chase you all the way through. It is all made worse because you CANNOT FIGHT BACK!Scariness - OK, this is the scariest game I've played, and I'll tell you why. The developers didn't rely on cheap jump scares. They put in pure scary content, the monsters ('servants') are scarier than all hell, you panic when you even hear one of these creatures. When you run out of lighting resources (tinderboxes and lantern oil), you panic. When you enter certain areas, you know you are going to encounter these things just by looking through the entrance.Cons:Voice Acting - The voice acting in this game is subpar. Yes I understand that this isn't an A-list game, but you can get some better voice acting in here.Character Design - Every body except the servants in this game are complete♥♥♥♥♥♥ The living humans you come across in this game have horrible design. The dead humans you come across in this game have horrible design. I know this is a strange thing to point out, but the naked bodies in this game are made like♥♥♥♥♥♥ The male bodies' junk is just a cylindrical lump on the body. My point is, if you can't make a body part right, cover it up, especially if it is an unessiantial body part to look at, like a♥♥♥♥♥♥♥The Ending - I won't spoil anything but I'll throw spoiler tags on it anyway...  The ending is quick, and then just done with. Roll credits Verdict:Even though this game has some issues, it is still a good game. You'll mainly enjoy it for the scares though, as the voices and graphics kill your vibe outside of the parts where you are running or hiding from the servants. This game is worth full price because it is only $20, and the amount of scary content you get in this game is worth it. It also has a decent replay value to it because you can get your friends to play this, and watch them spaz out while they play it. Recommended to anybody looking for some good scares.My rating: 6/10
